title: England
text:
England is a <a href="Countries%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">country</a> that is part of the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>. It shares land borders with <a href="Wales">Wales</a> to its west and <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a> to its north. The <a href="Irish%20Sea">Irish Sea</a> lies northwest of England and the <a href="Celtic%20Sea">Celtic Sea</a> to the southwest. England is separated from <a href="continental%20Europe">continental Europe</a> by the <a href="North%20Sea">North Sea</a> to the east and the <a href="English%20Channel">English Channel</a> to the south. The country covers five-eighths of the island of <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a>, which lies in the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean%23Northern%20Atlantic">North Atlantic</a>, and includes <a href="List%20of%20islands%20of%20England">over 100 smaller islands</a>, such as the <a href="Isles%20of%20Scilly">Isles of Scilly</a> and the <a href="Isle%20of%20Wight">Isle of Wight</a>.
The area now called England was first inhabited by modern humans during the <a href="Upper%20Paleolithic">Upper Paleolithic</a> period, but takes its name from the <a href="Angles">Angles</a>, a <a href="Germanic%20peoples">Germanic</a> tribe deriving its name from the <a href="Anglia%20%28peninsula%29">Anglia</a> peninsula, who settled during the 5th and 6th centuries. England became a unified state in the 10th century and has had a significant cultural and legal impact on the wider world since the <a href="Age%20of%20Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>, which began during the 15th century. The <a href="English%20language">English language</a>, the <a href="Anglican%20Communion">Anglican Church</a>, and <a href="English%20law">English law</a>—the basis for the <a href="common%20law">common law</a> legal systems of many other countries around the world—developed in England, and the country's <a href="Parliament%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">parliamentary system</a> of government has been widely adopted by other nations. The <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> began in 18th-century England, transforming its society into the world's first industrialised nation.
England's terrain is chiefly low hills and <a href="plain">plain</a>s, especially in central and southern England. However, there is upland and mountainous terrain in the north (for example, the <a href="Lake%20District">Lake District</a> and <a href="Pennines">Pennines</a>) and in the west (for example, <a href="Dartmoor">Dartmoor</a> and the <a href="Shropshire%20Hills">Shropshire Hills</a>). The capital is <a href="London">London</a>, which has the largest metropolitan area in the United Kingdom. England's population of 56.3 million comprises 84% of the population of the United Kingdom, largely concentrated around London, the <a href="South%20East%20England">South East</a>, and conurbations in the <a href="Midlands">Midlands</a>, the <a href="North%20West%20England">North West</a>, the <a href="North%20East%20England">North East</a>, and <a href="Yorkshire">Yorkshire</a>, which each developed as major industrial regions during the 19th century.
The <a href="Kingdom%20of%20England">Kingdom of England</a> – which after 1535 included Wales – ceased being a separate <a href="sovereign%20state">sovereign state</a> on 1 May 1707, when the <a href="Acts%20of%20Union%201707">Acts of Union</a> put into effect the terms agreed in the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Union">Treaty of Union</a> the previous year, resulting in a political union with the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Scotland">Kingdom of Scotland</a> to create the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain">Kingdom of Great Britain</a>. In 1801, Great Britain was united with the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Ireland">Kingdom of Ireland</a> (through another <a href="Acts%20of%20Union%201800">Act of Union</a>) to become the <a href="United%20Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20Ireland">United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland</a>. In 1922 the <a href="Irish%20Free%20State">Irish Free State</a> seceded from the United Kingdom, leading to the latter being <a href="Royal%20and%20Parliamentary%20Titles%20Act%201927">renamed</a> the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
Toponymy.
The name "England" is derived from the <a href="Old%20English">Old English</a> name "Englaland", which means "land of the <a href="Angles">Angles</a>". The Angles were one of the <a href="Germanic%20tribes">Germanic tribes</a> that settled in Great Britain during the <a href="Early%20Middle%20Ages">Early Middle Ages</a>. The Angles came from the <a href="Anglia%20%28peninsula%29">Anglia</a> peninsula in the <a href="Bay%20of%20Kiel">Bay of Kiel</a> area (present-day German state of <a href="Schleswig%E2%80%93Holstein">Schleswig–Holstein</a>) of the <a href="Baltic%20Sea">Baltic Sea</a>. The earliest recorded use of the term, as "Engla londe", is in the late-ninth-century translation into <a href="Old%20English">Old English</a> of <a href="Bede">Bede</a>'s "<a href="Ecclesiastical%20History%20of%20the%20English%20People">Ecclesiastical History of the English People</a>". The term was then used in a different sense to the modern one, meaning "the land inhabited by the English", and it included English people in what is now south-east Scotland but was then part of the English kingdom of <a href="Northumbria">Northumbria</a>. The "<a href="Anglo-Saxon%20Chronicle">Anglo-Saxon Chronicle</a>" recorded that the <a href="Domesday%20Book">Domesday Book</a> of 1086 covered the whole of England, meaning the English kingdom, but a few years later the "Chronicle" stated that King <a href="Malcolm%20III">Malcolm III</a> went "out of Scotlande into <a href="Lothian">Lothian</a> in Englaland", thus using it in the more ancient sense.
The earliest attested reference to the Angles occurs in the 1st-century work by <a href="Tacitus">Tacitus</a>, "<a href="Germania%20%28book%29">Germania</a>", in which the <a href="Latin">Latin</a> word "Anglii" is used. The etymology of the tribal name itself is disputed by scholars; it has been suggested that it derives from the shape of the Angeln peninsula, an "angular" shape. How and why a term derived from the name of a tribe that was less significant than others, such as the <a href="Saxons">Saxons</a>, came to be used for the entire country and its people is not known, but it seems this is related to the custom of calling the Germanic people in Britain "Angli Saxones" or English Saxons to distinguish them from continental Saxons (Eald-Seaxe) of Old Saxony between the Weser and Eider rivers in Northern Germany. In <a href="Scottish%20Gaelic">Scottish Gaelic</a>, another language which developed on the island of Great Britain, the Saxon tribe gave their name to the word for England ("Sasunn"); similarly, the Welsh name for the English language is "Saesneg". A romantic name for England is <a href="Lloegyr">Loegria</a>, related to the <a href="Welsh%20language">Welsh</a> word for England, "Lloegr", and made popular by its use in <a href="Arthurian%20legend">Arthurian legend</a>. "<a href="Albion">Albion</a>" is also applied to England in a more poetic capacity, though its original meaning is the island of Britain as a whole.
History.
Prehistory and antiquity.
The earliest known evidence of human presence in the area now known as England was that of "<a href="Homo%20antecessor">Homo antecessor</a>", dating to approximately 780,000 years ago. The oldest proto-human bones discovered in England date from 500,000 years ago. Modern humans are known to have inhabited the area during the <a href="Upper%20Paleolithic">Upper Paleolithic</a> period, though permanent settlements were only established within the last 6,000 years.
After the last <a href="Last%20glacial%20period">ice age</a> only large mammals such as <a href="mammoth">mammoth</a>s, <a href="bison">bison</a> and <a href="woolly%20rhinoceros">woolly rhinoceros</a> remained. Roughly 11,000 years ago, when the <a href="ice%20sheets">ice sheets</a> began to recede, humans repopulated the area; genetic research suggests they came from the northern part of the <a href="Iberian%20Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>. The sea level was lower than now and Britain was connected by <a href="land%20bridge">land bridge</a> to Ireland and <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>.
As the seas rose, it was separated from Ireland 10,000 years ago and from Eurasia two millennia later.
The <a href="Beaker%20culture">Beaker culture</a> arrived around 2,500 BC, introducing drinking and food vessels constructed from clay, as well as vessels used as reduction pots to smelt copper ores. It was during this time that major <a href="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> monuments such as <a href="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a> and <a href="Avebury">Avebury</a> were constructed. By heating together tin and copper, which were in abundance in the area, the Beaker culture people made <a href="bronze">bronze</a>, and later iron from iron ores. The development of iron <a href="smelting">smelting</a> allowed the construction of better <a href="plough">plough</a>s, advancing agriculture (for instance, with <a href="Celtic%20field">Celtic field</a>s), as well as the production of more effective weapons.
During the <a href="British%20Iron%20Age">Iron Age</a>, <a href="Celts">Celtic culture</a>, deriving from the <a href="Hallstatt%20culture">Hallstatt</a> and <a href="La%20T%C3%A8ne%20culture">La Tène culture</a>s, arrived from Central Europe. <a href="British%20language%20%28Celtic%29">Brythonic</a> was the spoken language during this time. Society was tribal; according to <a href="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a>'s "<a href="Geographia">Geographia</a>" there were around 20 tribes in the area. Earlier divisions are unknown because the Britons were not literate. Like other regions on the edge of the Empire, Britain had long enjoyed trading links with the Romans. Julius Caesar of the <a href="Roman%20Republic">Roman Republic</a> attempted to <a href="Caesar%27s%20invasions%20of%20Britain">invade twice</a> in 55 BC; although largely unsuccessful, he managed to set up a <a href="Roman%20client%20kingdoms%20in%20Britain">client king</a> from the <a href="Trinovantes">Trinovantes</a>.
The Romans invaded Britain in 43 AD during the reign of Emperor <a href="Claudius">Claudius</a>, subsequently <a href="Roman%20conquest%20of%20Britain">conquering much of Britain</a>, and the area was incorporated into the Roman Empire as <a href="Roman%20Britain">Britannia province</a>. The best-known of the native tribes who attempted to resist were the <a href="Catuvellauni">Catuvellauni</a> led by <a href="Caratacus">Caratacus</a>. Later, an uprising led by <a href="Boudica">Boudica</a>, Queen of the <a href="Iceni">Iceni</a>, ended with Boudica's suicide following her defeat at the <a href="Defeat%20of%20Boudica">Battle of Watling Street</a>. The author of one study of Roman Britain suggested that from 43 AD to 84 AD, the Roman invaders killed somewhere between 100,000 and 250,000 people from a population of perhaps 2,000,000. This era saw a <a href="Greco-Roman">Greco-Roman</a> culture prevail with the introduction of <a href="Roman%20law">Roman law</a>, <a href="Roman%20architecture">Roman architecture</a>, <a href="List%20of%20aqueducts%20in%20the%20Roman%20Empire">aqueducts</a>, <a href="Sanitation%20in%20ancient%20Rome">sewers</a>, many agricultural items and silk. In the 3rd century, Emperor <a href="Septimius%20Severus">Septimius Severus</a> died at <a href="Eboracum">Eboracum</a> (now <a href="York">York</a>), where <a href="Constantine%20the%20Great">Constantine</a> was subsequently proclaimed emperor a century later.
There is debate about when Christianity was first introduced; it was no later than the 4th century, probably much earlier. According to <a href="Bede">Bede</a>, missionaries were sent from Rome by <a href="Pope%20Eleuterus">Eleutherius</a> at the request of the chieftain <a href="Lucius%20of%20Britain">Lucius of Britain</a> in 180 AD, to settle differences as to Eastern and Western ceremonials, which were disturbing the church. There are traditions linked to Glastonbury claiming an introduction through <a href="Joseph%20of%20Arimathea">Joseph of Arimathea</a>, while others claim through <a href="Lucius%20of%20Britain">Lucius of Britain</a>. By 410, during the <a href="Decline%20of%20the%20Roman%20Empire">Decline of the Roman Empire</a>, Britain was left exposed by the <a href="end%20of%20Roman%20rule%20in%20Britain">end of Roman rule in Britain</a> and the withdrawal of Roman army units, to defend the frontiers in continental Europe and partake in civil wars. Celtic Christian monastic and missionary movements flourished: <a href="Saint%20Patrick">Patrick</a> (5th-century Ireland) and in the 6th century Brendan (Clonfert), Comgall (Bangor), David (Wales), Aiden (Lindisfarne) and Columba (Iona). This period of Christianity was influenced by ancient Celtic culture in its sensibilities, polity, practices and theology. Local "congregations" were centred in the monastic community and monastic leaders were more like chieftains, as peers, rather than in the more hierarchical system of the Roman-dominated church.
Middle Ages.
<a href="Military%20of%20ancient%20Rome">Roman military</a> withdrawals left Britain open to invasion by pagan, seafaring warriors from north-western continental Europe, chiefly the Saxons, <a href="Angles">Angles</a>, <a href="Jutes">Jutes</a> and Frisians who had long raided the coasts of the Roman province. These groups then began to settle in increasing numbers over the course of the fifth and sixth centuries, initially in the eastern part of the country. Their advance was contained for some decades after the Britons' victory at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Badon">Battle of Mount Badon</a>, but subsequently resumed, overrunning the fertile lowlands of Britain and reducing the area under <a href="Britons%20%28historical%29">Brittonic</a> control to a series of separate enclaves in the more rugged country to the west by the end of the 6th century. Contemporary texts describing this period are extremely scarce, giving rise to its description as a <a href="Dark%20Age">Dark Age</a>. The nature and progression of the <a href="Anglo-Saxon%20settlement%20of%20Britain">Anglo-Saxon settlement of Britain</a> is consequently subject to considerable disagreement; the emerging consensus is that it occurred on a large scale in the south and east but was less substantial to the north and west, where Celtic languages continued to be spoken even in areas under Anglo-Saxon control. Roman-dominated Christianity had, in general, been replaced in the conquered territories by <a href="Anglo-Saxon%20paganism">Anglo-Saxon paganism</a>, but was reintroduced by missionaries from Rome led by <a href="Augustine%20of%20Canterbury">Augustine</a> from 597 onwards. Disputes between the Roman- and Celtic-dominated forms of Christianity ended in victory for the Roman tradition at the <a href="Council%20of%20Whitby">Council of Whitby</a> (664), which was ostensibly about <a href="tonsure">tonsure</a>s (clerical haircuts) and the date of Easter, but more significantly, about the differences in Roman and Celtic forms of authority, theology, and practice.
During the settlement period the lands ruled by the incomers seem to have been fragmented into numerous tribal territories, but by the 7th century, when substantial evidence of the situation again becomes available, these had coalesced into roughly a dozen kingdoms including <a href="Northumbria">Northumbria</a>, <a href="Mercia">Mercia</a>, <a href="Wessex">Wessex</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20East%20Anglia">East Anglia</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Essex">Essex</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Kent">Kent</a> and <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Sussex">Sussex</a>. Over the following centuries, this process of political consolidation continued. The 7th century saw a struggle for hegemony between Northumbria and Mercia, which in the 8th century gave way to Mercian preeminence. In the early 9th century Mercia was displaced as the foremost kingdom by Wessex. Later in that century escalating attacks by the <a href="Danes%20%28Germanic%20tribe%29">Danes</a> culminated in the conquest of the north and east of England, overthrowing the kingdoms of Northumbria, Mercia and East Anglia. Wessex under <a href="Alfred%20the%20Great">Alfred the Great</a> was left as the only surviving English kingdom, and under his successors, it steadily expanded at the expense of the kingdoms of the <a href="Danelaw">Danelaw</a>. This brought about the political unification of England, first accomplished under <a href="%C3%86thelstan">Æthelstan</a> in 927 and definitively established after further conflicts by <a href="Eadred">Eadred</a> in 953. A fresh wave of Scandinavian attacks from the late 10th century ended with the conquest of this united kingdom by <a href="Sweyn%20Forkbeard">Sweyn Forkbeard</a> in 1013 and again by his son <a href="Cnut%20the%20Great">Cnut</a> in 1016, turning it into the centre of a short-lived <a href="North%20Sea%20Empire">North Sea Empire</a> that also included <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Denmark">Denmark</a> and <a href="Norway">Norway</a>. However, the native royal dynasty was restored with the accession of <a href="Edward%20the%20Confessor">Edward the Confessor</a> in 1042.
A dispute over the succession to Edward led to the <a href="Norman%20Conquest">Norman Conquest</a> in 1066, accomplished by an army led by <a href="William%20the%20Conqueror">Duke William of Normandy</a>. The <a href="Normans">Normans</a> themselves originated from <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a> and had settled in Normandy in the late 9th and early 10th centuries. This conquest led to the almost total dispossession of the English elite and its replacement by a new French-speaking aristocracy, whose speech had a profound and permanent effect on the English language.
Subsequently, the <a href="House%20of%20Plantagenet">House of Plantagenet</a> from Anjou inherited the English throne under <a href="Henry%20II%20of%20England">Henry II</a>, adding England to the budding <a href="Angevin%20Empire">Angevin Empire</a> of fiefs the family had inherited in France including <a href="Duchy%20of%20Aquitaine">Aquitaine</a>. They reigned for three centuries, some noted monarchs being <a href="Richard%20I%20of%20England">Richard I</a>, <a href="Edward%20I%20of%20England">Edward I</a>, <a href="Edward%20III%20of%20England">Edward III</a> and <a href="Henry%20V%20of%20England">Henry V</a>. The period saw changes in trade and legislation, including the signing of the "<a href="Magna%20Carta">Magna Carta</a>", an English legal charter used to limit the sovereign's powers by law and protect the privileges of freemen. Catholic <a href="monasticism">monasticism</a> flourished, providing philosophers, and the universities of Oxford and Cambridge were founded with royal patronage. The <a href="Principality%20of%20Wales">Principality of Wales</a> became a Plantagenet fief during the 13th century and the <a href="Lordship%20of%20Ireland">Lordship of Ireland</a> was given to the English monarchy by the Pope.
During the 14th century, the Plantagenets and the <a href="House%20of%20Valois">House of Valois</a> both claimed to be legitimate claimants to the <a href="House%20of%20Capet">House of Capet</a> and with it France; the two powers clashed in the <a href="Hundred%20Years%27%20War">Hundred Years' War</a>. The <a href="Black%20Death">Black Death</a> epidemic <a href="Black%20Death%20in%20England">hit England</a>; starting in 1348, it eventually killed up to half of England's <a href="Medieval%20demography">inhabitants</a>. From 1453 to 1487 civil war occurred between two branches of the royal family – the <a href="House%20of%20York">Yorkists</a> and <a href="House%20of%20Lancaster">Lancastrians</a> – known as the <a href="Wars%20of%20the%20Roses">Wars of the Roses</a>. Eventually it led to the Yorkists losing the throne entirely to a Welsh noble family the <a href="House%20of%20Tudor">Tudors</a>, a branch of the Lancastrians headed by <a href="Henry%20VII%20of%20England">Henry Tudor</a> who invaded with Welsh and Breton mercenaries, gaining victory at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Bosworth%20Field">Battle of Bosworth Field</a> where the Yorkist king <a href="Richard%20III%20of%20England">Richard III</a> was killed.
Early modern.
During the <a href="Tudor%20period">Tudor period</a>, the <a href="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> reached England through Italian courtiers, who reintroduced artistic, educational and scholarly debate from classical antiquity. England began to develop <a href="English%20Navy">naval skills</a>, and exploration to the West intensified. <a href="Henry%20VIII%20of%20England">Henry VIII</a> broke from communion with the Catholic Church, over issues relating to his divorce, under the <a href="Acts%20of%20Supremacy">Acts of Supremacy</a> in 1534 which proclaimed the monarch head of the <a href="Church%20of%20England">Church of England</a>. In contrast with much of European Protestantism, the <a href="English%20Reformation">roots of the split</a> were more political than theological. He also legally incorporated his ancestral land Wales into the Kingdom of England with the <a href="Laws%20in%20Wales%20Acts%201535%E2%80%931542">1535–1542 acts</a>. There were internal religious conflicts during the reigns of Henry's daughters, <a href="Mary%20I%20of%20England">Mary I</a> and <a href="Elizabeth%20I%20of%20England">Elizabeth I</a>. The former took the country back to Catholicism while the latter broke from it again, forcefully asserting the supremacy of <a href="Anglicanism">Anglicanism</a>. The <a href="Elizabethan%20era">Elizabethan era</a> is the epoch in the <a href="Tudor%20period">Tudor age</a> of the reign of <a href="Queen%20Elizabeth%20I">Queen Elizabeth I</a> ("the Virgin Queen"). Historians often depict it as the <a href="Golden%20age%20%28metaphor%29">golden age</a> in English history. <a href="Elizabethan%20era">Elizabethan England</a> represented the apogee of the <a href="English%20Renaissance">English Renaissance</a> and saw the flowering of art, poetry, music and literature. The era is most famous for its drama, theatre and playwrights. England during this period had a centralised, well-organised, and effective government as a result of vast Tudor reforms. 
Competing with <a href="Spanish%20Empire">Spain</a>, the first English colony in the Americas was founded in 1585 by explorer <a href="Walter%20Raleigh">Walter Raleigh</a> in <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a> and named <a href="Roanoke%20Colony">Roanoke</a>. The Roanoke colony failed and is known as the lost colony after it was found abandoned on the return of the late-arriving supply ship. With the <a href="East%20India%20Company">East India Company</a>, England also competed with the <a href="Dutch%20Empire">Dutch</a> and <a href="French%20colonial%20empire">French</a> in the East. During the <a href="Elizabethan%20period">Elizabethan period</a>, England was at war with Spain. An <a href="Spanish%20Armada">armada</a> sailed from Spain in 1588 as part of a wider plan to invade England and re-establish a Catholic monarchy. The plan was thwarted by bad coordination, stormy weather and successful harrying attacks by an English fleet under <a href="Charles%20Howard%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Nottingham">Lord Howard of Effingham</a>. This failure did not end the threat: Spain launched two further armadas, in <a href="2nd%20Spanish%20Armada">1596</a> and <a href="3rd%20Spanish%20Armada">1597</a>, but both were driven back by storms. The political structure of the island changed in 1603, when the <a href="King%20of%20Scots">King of Scots</a>, <a href="James%20VI%20of%20Scotland">James VI</a>, a kingdom which had been a long-time rival to English interests, inherited the throne of England as <a href="James%20VI%20and%20I">James I</a>, thereby creating a <a href="Union%20of%20the%20Crowns">personal union</a>. He styled himself <a href="King%20of%20Great%20Britain">King of Great Britain</a>, although this had no basis in English law. Under the auspices of King James VI and I the Authorised <a href="King%20James%20Version">King James Version</a> of the Holy Bible was published in 1611. It was the standard version of the Bible read by most Protestant Christians for four hundred years until modern revisions were produced in the 20th century.
Based on conflicting political, religious and social positions, the <a href="English%20Civil%20War">English Civil War</a> was fought between the supporters of <a href="Long%20Parliament">Parliament</a> and those of King <a href="Charles%20I%20of%20England">Charles I</a>, known colloquially as <a href="Roundhead">Roundhead</a>s and <a href="Cavalier">Cavalier</a>s respectively. This was an interwoven part of the wider multifaceted <a href="Wars%20of%20the%20Three%20Kingdoms">Wars of the Three Kingdoms</a>, involving <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Scotland">Scotland</a> and <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Ireland">Ireland</a>. The Parliamentarians were victorious, <a href="execution%20of%20Charles%20I">Charles I was executed</a> and the kingdom replaced by the <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20England">Commonwealth</a>. Leader of the Parliament forces, <a href="Oliver%20Cromwell">Oliver Cromwell</a> declared himself <a href="Lord%20Protector">Lord Protector</a> in 1653; a period of <a href="the%20Protectorate">personal rule</a> followed. After Cromwell's death and the resignation of his son <a href="Richard%20Cromwell">Richard</a> as Lord Protector, <a href="Charles%20II%20of%20England">Charles II</a> was invited to return as monarch in 1660, in a move called the <a href="English%20Restoration">Restoration</a>. With the reopening of theatres, fine arts, literature and performing arts flourished throughout the <a href="English%20Restoration">Restoration</a> of "the Merry Monarch" <a href="Charles%20II%20of%20England">Charles II</a>. After the <a href="Glorious%20Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a> of 1688, it was constitutionally established that King and Parliament should rule together, though Parliament would have the real power. This was established with the <a href="Bill%20of%20Rights%201689">Bill of Rights</a> in 1689. Among the statutes set down were that the law could only be made by Parliament and could not be suspended by the King, also that the King could not impose taxes or raise an army without the prior approval of Parliament. Also since that time, no British monarch has entered the <a href="House%20of%20Commons%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">House of Commons</a> when it is sitting, which is annually commemorated at the <a href="State%20Opening%20of%20Parliament">State Opening of Parliament</a> by the British monarch when the doors of the House of Commons are slammed in the face of the monarch's messenger, symbolising the rights of Parliament and its independence from the monarch. With the founding of the <a href="Royal%20Society">Royal Society</a> in 1660, science was greatly encouraged.
In 1666 the <a href="Great%20Fire%20of%20London">Great Fire of London</a> gutted the City of London but it was rebuilt shortly afterwards with many significant buildings designed by Sir <a href="Christopher%20Wren">Christopher Wren</a>. In Parliament two factions had emerged – the <a href="Tory">Tories</a> and <a href="Whig%20%28British%20political%20faction%29">Whigs</a>. Though the Tories initially supported Catholic king <a href="James%20II%20of%20England">James II</a>, some of them, along with the Whigs, during the <a href="Glorious%20Revolution">Revolution of 1688</a> invited Dutch prince William of Orange to defeat James and ultimately to become <a href="William%20III%20of%20England">William III of England</a>. Some English people, especially in the north, were <a href="Jacobitism">Jacobites</a> and continued to support James and his sons. Under the <a href="House%20of%20Stuart">Stuart dynasty</a> England expanded in trade, finance and prosperity. Britain developed Europe's largest merchant fleet. After the parliaments of England and Scotland agreed, the two countries joined in <a href="political%20union">political union</a>, to create the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain">Kingdom of Great Britain</a> in 1707. To accommodate the union, institutions such as the law and national churches of each remained separate.
Late modern and contemporary.
Under the newly formed Kingdom of Great Britain, output from the Royal Society and other <a href="English%20Enlightenment">English initiatives</a> combined with the <a href="Scottish%20Enlightenment">Scottish Enlightenment</a> to create innovations in science and engineering, while the enormous growth in <a href="Triangular%20trade">British overseas trade</a> protected by the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> paved the way for the establishment of the <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a>. Domestically it drove the <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>, a period of profound change in the <a href="socioeconomics">socioeconomic</a> and cultural conditions of England, resulting in industrialised agriculture, manufacture, engineering and mining, as well as new and pioneering road, rail and water networks to facilitate their expansion and development. The opening of Northwest England's <a href="Bridgewater%20Canal">Bridgewater Canal</a> in 1761 ushered in the <a href="History%20of%20the%20British%20canal%20system">canal age in Britain</a>. In 1825 the world's first permanent steam locomotive-hauled passenger railway – the <a href="Stockton%20and%20Darlington%20Railway">Stockton and Darlington Railway</a> – opened to the public. 
During the Industrial Revolution, many workers moved from England's countryside to new and expanding urban industrial areas to work in factories, for instance at <a href="Birmingham">Birmingham</a> and <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>, dubbed "Workshop of the World" and "Warehouse City" respectively. Manchester was the world's first industrial city. England maintained relative stability throughout the <a href="French%20Revolution">French Revolution</a>; <a href="William%20Pitt%20the%20Younger">William Pitt the Younger</a> was British Prime Minister for the reign of <a href="George%20III%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">George III</a>. The Regency of <a href="George%20IV">George IV</a> is noted for its elegance and achievements in the fine arts and architecture. During the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, <a href="Napoleon">Napoleon</a> planned to <a href="Napoleon%27s%20planned%20invasion%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">invade from the south-east</a>. However this failed to manifest and the Napoleonic forces were defeated by the British: at sea by <a href="Horatio%20Nelson%2C%201st%20Viscount%20Nelson">Lord Nelson</a>, and on land by the <a href="Arthur%20Wellesley%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Wellington">Duke of Wellington</a>. The major victory at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Trafalgar">Battle of Trafalgar</a> confirmed the naval supremacy Britain had established during the course of the eighteenth century. The Napoleonic Wars fostered a concept of <a href="Britishness">Britishness</a> and a united national <a href="British%20people">British people</a>, shared with the English, Scots and Welsh.
London became the largest and most populous metropolitan area in the world during the <a href="Victorian%20era">Victorian era</a>, and trade within the British Empire – as well as the standing of the British military and navy – was prestigious. Technologically, this era saw many innovations that proved key to the United Kingdom's power and prosperity. Political agitation at home from radicals such as the <a href="Chartism">Chartists</a> and the <a href="suffragette">suffragette</a>s enabled legislative reform and <a href="universal%20suffrage">universal suffrage</a>. <a href="Samuel%20Hynes">Samuel Hynes</a> described the <a href="Edwardian%20era">Edwardian era</a> as a "leisurely time when women wore <a href="Picture%20hat">picture hats</a> and did not vote, when the rich were not ashamed to live conspicuously, and the sun really never set on the British flag."
Power shifts in east-central Europe led to World War I; hundreds of thousands of English soldiers died fighting for the United Kingdom as part of the <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20I">Allies</a>. Two decades later, in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the United Kingdom was again one of the <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">Allies</a>. At the end of the <a href="Phoney%20War">Phoney War</a>, <a href="Winston%20Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> became the wartime Prime Minister. Developments in warfare technology saw many cities damaged by air-raids during <a href="the%20Blitz">the Blitz</a>. Following the war, the British Empire experienced rapid <a href="decolonisation">decolonisation</a>, and there was a speeding-up of technological innovations; automobiles became the primary means of transport and <a href="Frank%20Whittle">Frank Whittle</a>'s development of the <a href="jet%20engine">jet engine</a> led to wider <a href="air%20travel">air travel</a>. Residential patterns were altered in England by private motoring, and by the creation of the <a href="National%20Health%20Service%20%28England%29">National Health Service</a> (NHS) in 1948. The UK's NHS provided <a href="publicly%20funded%20health%20care">publicly funded health care</a> to all UK permanent residents free at the point of need, being paid for from general taxation. Combined, these prompted the reform of <a href="local%20government%20in%20England">local government in England</a> in the mid-20th century.
Since the 20th century there has been significant population movement to England, mostly from other parts of the <a href="British%20Isles">British Isles</a>, but also from the <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth</a>, particularly the <a href="Indian%20subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>. Since the 1970s there has been a large move away from manufacturing and an increasing emphasis on the <a href="service%20industry">service industry</a>. As part of the United Kingdom, the area joined a <a href="common%20market">common market</a> initiative called the <a href="European%20Economic%20Community">European Economic Community</a> which became the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>. Since the late 20th century the <a href="politics%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">administration of the United Kingdom</a> has moved towards <a href="devolution">devolved governance</a> in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. <a href="England%20and%20Wales">England and Wales</a> continues to exist as a jurisdiction within the United Kingdom. Devolution has stimulated a greater emphasis on a more English-specific identity and patriotism. There is no devolved English government, but an attempt to create a similar system on a sub-regional basis was rejected by referendum.
Governance.
Politics.
England is part of the United Kingdom, a <a href="constitutional%20monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> with a <a href="parliamentary%20system">parliamentary system</a>. There has not been a <a href="government%20of%20England">government of England</a> since 1707, when the <a href="Acts%20of%20Union%201707">Acts of Union 1707</a>, putting into effect the terms of the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Union">Treaty of Union</a>, joined England and Scotland to form the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain">Kingdom of Great Britain</a>. Before the union England was ruled by <a href="List%20of%20English%20monarchs">its monarch</a> and the <a href="Parliament%20of%20England">Parliament of England</a>. Today England is governed directly by the <a href="Parliament%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Parliament of the United Kingdom</a>, although other <a href="countries%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">countries of the United Kingdom</a> have <a href="Devolution">devolved</a> governments. In the <a href="House%20of%20Commons%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">House of Commons</a> which is the <a href="lower%20house">lower house</a> of the British Parliament based at the <a href="Palace%20of%20Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>, there are 532 Members of Parliament (MPs) for constituencies in England, out of the 650 total. As of the <a href="2019%20United%20Kingdom%20general%20election">2019 United Kingdom general election</a>, England is represented by 345 MPs from the <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative Party</a>, 179 from the <a href="Labour%20Party%20%28UK%29">Labour Party</a>, seven from the <a href="Liberal%20Democrats%20%28UK%29">Liberal Democrats</a>, one from the <a href="Green%20Party%20of%20England%20and%20Wales">Green Party</a>, and the <a href="Speaker%20of%20the%20House%20of%20Commons%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Speaker of the House</a>, <a href="Lindsay%20Hoyle">Lindsay Hoyle</a>.
Since <a href="devolution">devolution</a>, in which other countries of the United Kingdom – Scotland, Wales and <a href="Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> – each have their own devolved parliament or assemblies for local issues, there has been debate about how to counterbalance this in England. Originally it was planned that various <a href="regions%20of%20England">regions of England</a> would be devolved, but following the proposal's rejection by the <a href="North%20East%20England">North East</a> in a <a href="2004%20North%20East%20England%20devolution%20referendum">2004 referendum</a>, this has not been carried out.
One major issue is the <a href="West%20Lothian%20question">West Lothian question</a>, in which MPs from Scotland and Wales are able to vote on legislation affecting only England, while English MPs have no equivalent right to legislate on devolved matters. This when placed in the context of England being the only country of the United Kingdom not to have free cancer treatment, prescriptions, residential care for the elderly and <a href="top-up%20fees">free top-up university fees</a>, has led to a steady rise in <a href="English%20nationalism">English nationalism</a>. Some have suggested the creation of a <a href="devolved%20English%20parliament">devolved English parliament</a>, while others have proposed simply limiting voting on legislation which only affects England to English MPs.
Law.
The <a href="English%20law">English law</a> legal system, developed over the centuries, is the basis of <a href="common%20law">common law</a> legal systems used in most <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth</a> countries and the United States (except <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>). Despite now being part of the United Kingdom, the legal system of the <a href="Courts%20of%20England%20and%20Wales">Courts of England and Wales</a> continued, under the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Union">Treaty of Union</a>, as a separate legal system from the one used in Scotland. The general essence of English law is that it is made by judges sitting in courts, applying their common sense and knowledge of <a href="legal%20precedent">legal precedent</a> – "<a href="stare%20decisis">stare decisis</a>" – to the facts before them.
The <a href="Courts%20of%20England%20and%20Wales">court system</a> is headed by the Senior Courts of England and Wales, consisting of the <a href="Court%20of%20Appeal%20of%20England%20and%20Wales">Court of Appeal</a>, the <a href="High%20Court%20of%20Justice">High Court of Justice</a> for civil cases, and the <a href="Crown%20Court">Crown Court</a> for criminal cases. The <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Supreme Court of the United Kingdom</a> is the highest court for criminal and civil cases in <a href="England%20and%20Wales">England and Wales</a>. It was created in 2009 after constitutional changes, taking over the <a href="judicial%20functions%20of%20the%20House%20of%20Lords">judicial functions of the House of Lords</a>. A decision of the Supreme Court is binding on every other court in the hierarchy, which must follow its directions. 
The <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Justice">Secretary of State for Justice</a> is the minister responsible to Parliament for the <a href="Judiciaries%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">judiciary</a>, the court system and prisons and probation in England. Crime increased between 1981 and 1995 but fell by 42% in the period 1995–2006. The prison population doubled over the same period, giving it one of <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20incarceration%20rate">highest incarceration rate</a> in Western Europe at 147 per 100,000. <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Prison%20Service">Her Majesty's Prison Service</a>, reporting to the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Justice%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Ministry of Justice</a>, manages most <a href="prisons%20in%20England">prisons</a>, housing over 85,000 convicts.
Regions, counties, and districts.
The <a href="subdivisions%20of%20England">subdivisions of England</a> consist of up to four levels of <a href="administrative%20division">subnational division</a> controlled through a variety of types of administrative entities created for the purposes of <a href="local%20government%20in%20England">local government</a>. The highest tier of local government were the nine <a href="regions%20of%20England">regions of England</a>: <a href="North%20East%20England">North East</a>, <a href="North%20West%20England">North West</a>, <a href="Yorkshire%20and%20the%20Humber">Yorkshire and the Humber</a>, <a href="East%20Midlands">East Midlands</a>, <a href="West%20Midlands%20%28region%29">West Midlands</a>, <a href="East%20of%20England">East</a>, <a href="South%20East%20England">South East</a>, <a href="South%20West%20England">South West</a>, and London. These were created in 1994 as <a href="Government%20Office">Government Office</a>s, used by the UK government to deliver a wide range of policies and programmes regionally, but there are no elected bodies at this level, except in London, and in 2011 the regional government offices were abolished.
After <a href="devolution">devolution</a> began to take place in other parts of the United Kingdom it was planned that referendums for the regions of England would take place for their own elected <a href="Regional%20Assemblies%20in%20England">regional assemblies</a> as a counterweight. <a href="1998%20Greater%20London%20Authority%20referendum">London accepted</a> in 1998: the <a href="London%20Assembly">London Assembly</a> was created two years later. However, when the proposal was rejected by the <a href="2004%20North%20East%20England%20devolution%20referendum">2004 North East England devolution referendum</a> in the North East, further referendums were cancelled. The regional assemblies outside London were abolished in 2010, and their functions transferred to respective <a href="Regional%20Development%20Agency">Regional Development Agencies</a> and a new system of <a href="Local%20authority%20leaders%27%20boards">Local authority leaders' boards</a>.
Below the regional level, all of England is divided into 48 <a href="Ceremonial%20counties%20of%20England">ceremonial counties</a>. These are used primarily as a geographical frame of reference and have developed gradually since the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a>, with some established as recently as 1974. Each has a <a href="Lord%20Lieutenant">Lord Lieutenant</a> and <a href="High%20Sheriff">High Sheriff</a>; these posts are used to represent the <a href="British%20monarch">British monarch</a> locally. Outside <a href="Greater%20London">Greater London</a> and the <a href="Isles%20of%20Scilly">Isles of Scilly</a>, England is also divided into 83 <a href="Metropolitan%20and%20non-metropolitan%20counties%20of%20England">metropolitan and non-metropolitan counties</a>; these correspond to areas used for the purposes of local government and may consist of a single district or be divided into several.
There are six <a href="metropolitan%20county">metropolitan counties</a> based on the most heavily urbanised areas, which do not have county councils. In these areas the principal authorities are the councils of the subdivisions, the <a href="metropolitan%20borough">metropolitan borough</a>s. Elsewhere, 27 <a href="non-metropolitan%20county">non-metropolitan "shire" counties</a> have a <a href="county%20council">county council</a> and are divided into districts, each with a district council. They are typically, though not always, found in more rural areas. The remaining non-metropolitan counties are of a single district and usually correspond to large towns or sparsely populated counties; they are known as <a href="Unitary%20authorities%20of%20England">unitary authorities</a>. Greater London has a different system for local government, with 32 <a href="London%20borough">London borough</a>s, plus the <a href="City%20of%20London">City of London</a> covering a small area at the core governed by the <a href="City%20of%20London%20Corporation">City of London Corporation</a>. At the most localised level, much of England is divided into <a href="civil%20parishes%20in%20England">civil parishes</a> with <a href="Parish%20councils%20in%20England">councils</a>; in Greater London only one, <a href="Queen%27s%20Park%2C%20London">Queen's Park</a>, exists after they were <a href="London%20Government%20Act%201963">abolished in 1965</a> until legislation <a href="Local%20Government%20and%20Public%20Involvement%20in%20Health%20Act%202007">allowed their recreation</a> in 2007.
Geography.
Landscape and rivers.
Geographically England includes the central and southern two-thirds of the island of Great Britain, plus such offshore islands as the <a href="Isle%20of%20Wight">Isle of Wight</a> and the <a href="Isles%20of%20Scilly">Isles of Scilly</a>. It is bordered by two other countries of the United Kingdom: <a href="Anglo%20Scottish%20border">to the north</a> by Scotland and <a href="Wales-England%20border">to the west</a> by Wales. England is closer than any other part of mainland Britain to the European continent. It is separated from <a href="France">France</a> (<a href="Hauts-de-France">Hauts-de-France</a>) by a sea gap, though the two countries are connected by the <a href="Channel%20Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a> near <a href="Folkestone">Folkestone</a>. England also has shores on the <a href="Irish%20Sea">Irish Sea</a>, <a href="North%20Sea">North Sea</a> and Atlantic Ocean.
The ports of London, <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a>, and <a href="Newcastle%20upon%20Tyne">Newcastle</a> lie on the tidal rivers <a href="River%20Thames">Thames</a>, <a href="River%20Mersey">Mersey</a> and <a href="River%20Tyne">Tyne</a> respectively. At , the <a href="River%20Severn">Severn</a> is the longest river flowing through England. It empties into the <a href="Bristol%20Channel">Bristol Channel</a> and is notable for its <a href="Severn%20Bore">Severn Bore</a> (a <a href="tidal%20bore">tidal bore</a>), which can reach in height. However, the longest river entirely in England is the Thames, which is in length.
There are many <a href="lakes%20in%20England">lakes in England</a>; the largest is <a href="Windermere">Windermere</a>, within the aptly named <a href="Lake%20District">Lake District</a>. Most of England's landscape consists of low hills and plains, with upland and mountainous terrain in the north and west of the country. The northern uplands include the <a href="Pennines">Pennines</a>, a chain of uplands dividing east and west, the Lake District mountains in Cumbria, and the <a href="Cheviot%20Hills">Cheviot Hills</a>, straddling the border between England and Scotland. The highest point in England, at , is <a href="Scafell%20Pike">Scafell Pike</a> in the Lake District. The <a href="Shropshire%20Hills">Shropshire Hills</a> are near Wales while <a href="Dartmoor">Dartmoor</a> and <a href="Exmoor">Exmoor</a> are two upland areas in the south-west of the country. The approximate dividing line between terrain types is often indicated by the <a href="Tees-Exe%20line">Tees-Exe line</a>.
In geological terms, the Pennines, known as the "backbone of England", are the oldest range of mountains in the country, originating from the end of the <a href="Paleozoic%20Era">Paleozoic Era</a> around 300 million years ago. Their geological composition includes, among others, <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a> and <a href="limestone">limestone</a>, and also coal. There are <a href="karst">karst</a> landscapes in calcite areas such as parts of <a href="Yorkshire">Yorkshire</a> and <a href="Derbyshire">Derbyshire</a>. The Pennine landscape is high <a href="moorland">moorland</a> in upland areas, indented by fertile valleys of the region's rivers. They contain two <a href="national%20parks%20in%20England">national parks</a>, the <a href="Yorkshire%20Dales">Yorkshire Dales</a> and the <a href="Peak%20District">Peak District</a>. In the <a href="West%20Country">West Country</a>, Dartmoor and Exmoor of the Southwest Peninsula include upland moorland supported by granite, and enjoy a <a href="Climate%20of%20south-west%20England">mild climate</a>; both are national parks.
The <a href="English%20Lowlands%20beech%20forests">English Lowlands</a> are in the central and southern regions of the country, consisting of green rolling hills, including the <a href="Cotswold%20Hills">Cotswold Hills</a>, <a href="Chiltern%20Hills">Chiltern Hills</a>, <a href="North%20Downs">North</a> and <a href="South%20Downs">South Downs</a>; where they meet the sea they form white rock exposures such as the <a href="cliffs%20of%20Dover">cliffs of Dover</a>. This also includes relatively flat plains such as the <a href="Salisbury%20Plain">Salisbury Plain</a>, <a href="Somerset%20Levels">Somerset Levels</a>, <a href="South%20Coast%20Plain">South Coast Plain</a> and <a href="The%20Fens">The Fens</a>.
Climate.
England has a <a href="temperate%20climate">temperate</a> <a href="maritime%20climate">maritime climate</a>: it is mild with temperatures not much lower than in winter and not much higher than in summer. The weather is damp relatively frequently and is changeable. The coldest months are January and February, the latter particularly on the <a href="Geography%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">English coast</a>, while July is normally the warmest month. Months with mild to warm weather are May, June, September and October. Rainfall is spread fairly evenly throughout the year.
Important influences on the climate of England are its proximity to the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, its northern <a href="latitude">latitude</a> and the warming of the sea by the <a href="Gulf%20Stream">Gulf Stream</a>. Rainfall is higher in the west, and parts of the <a href="Lake%20District">Lake District</a> receive more rain than anywhere else in the country. Since weather records began, the highest temperature recorded was on 25 July 2019 at the <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Botanic%20Garden">Botanic Garden</a> in <a href="Cambridge">Cambridge</a>, while the lowest was on 10 January 1982 in <a href="Edgmond%2C%20Shropshire">Edgmond</a>, Shropshire.
Nature and wildlife.
The fauna of England is similar to that of other areas in the <a href="British%20Isles">British Isles</a> with a wide range of vertebrate and invertebrate life in a diverse range of habitats.
<a href="National%20nature%20reserves%20in%20England">National nature reserves in England</a> are designated by <a href="Natural%20England">Natural England</a> as key places for <a href="wildlife">wildlife</a> and natural features in England. They were established to protect the most significant areas of habitat and of geological formations. NNRs are managed on behalf of the nation, many by Natural England themselves, but also by non-governmental organisations, including the members of <a href="The%20Wildlife%20Trusts">The Wildlife Trusts</a> partnership, the <a href="National%20Trust%20for%20Places%20of%20Historic%20Interest%20or%20Natural%20Beauty">National Trust</a>, and the <a href="Royal%20Society%20for%20the%20Protection%20of%20Birds">Royal Society for the Protection of Birds</a>. There are 229 NNRs in England covering . Often they contain rare species or nationally important species of plants and animals.
The <a href="Environment%20Agency">Environment Agency</a> is a <a href="non-departmental%20public%20body">non-departmental public body</a>, established in 1995 and sponsored by the <a href="Department%20for%20Environment%2C%20Food%20and%20Rural%20Affairs">Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs</a> with responsibilities relating to the protection and enhancement of the environment in England. The <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Environment%2C%20Food%20and%20Rural%20Affairs">Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs</a> is the minister responsible for environmental protection, agriculture, fisheries and rural communities in England.
England has a <a href="Oceanic%20climate">temperate oceanic climate</a> in most areas, lacking extremes of cold or heat, but does have a few small areas of <a href="Subarctic%20climate">subarctic</a> and warmer areas in <a href="South%20West%20England">the South West</a>. Towards the <a href="Northern%20England">North of England</a> the climate becomes colder and most of England's mountains and high hills are located here and have a major impact on the climate and thus the local fauna of the areas. <a href="Deciduous">Deciduous</a> woodlands are common across all of England and provide a great habitat for much of England's wildlife, but these give way in northern and upland areas of England to <a href="coniferous">coniferous</a> forests (mainly plantations) which also benefit certain forms of wildlife. Some species have adapted to the expanded urban environment, particularly the <a href="red%20fox">red fox</a>, which is the most successful <a href="Urban%20wildlife">urban mammal</a> after the <a href="brown%20rat">brown rat</a>, and other animals such as <a href="common%20wood%20pigeon">common wood pigeon</a>, both of which thrive in urban and suburban areas.
<a href="Grey%20squirrels">Grey squirrels</a> introduced from eastern America have forced the decline of the native red squirrel due to competition. <a href="Red%20squirrels">Red squirrels</a> are now confined to upland and coniferous-forested areas of England, mainly in the north, south west and Isle of Wight. England's climate is very suitable for lagomorphs and the country has rabbits and brown hares which were introduced in Roman times. Mountain hares which are indigenous have now been re-introduced in Derbyshire. The fauna of England has to cope with varying temperatures and conditions, although not extreme they do pose potential challenges and adaptational measures. English fauna has however had to cope with industrialisation, human population densities amongst the highest in <a href="Europe">Europe</a> and <a href="intensive%20farming">intensive farming</a>, but as England is a developed nation, wildlife and the countryside have entered the <a href="English%20people">English</a> mindset more and the country is very conscientious about preserving its wildlife, environment and countryside.
Major conurbations.
The <a href="Greater%20London%20Built-up%20Area">Greater London Built-up Area</a> is by far the largest urban area in England and one of the busiest cities in the world. It is considered a <a href="global%20city">global city</a> and has a population larger than any other country in the United Kingdom besides England itself. Other urban areas of considerable size and influence tend to be in <a href="northern%20England">northern England</a> or the <a href="English%20Midlands">English Midlands</a>. There are <a href="List%20of%20cities%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">50 settlements</a> which have designated <a href="City%20status%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">city status in England</a>, while the wider United Kingdom has 66.
While many cities in England are quite large, such as <a href="Birmingham">Birmingham</a>, <a href="Sheffield">Sheffield</a>, <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a>, <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a>, <a href="City%20of%20Leeds">Leeds</a>, <a href="Newcastle%20upon%20Tyne">Newcastle</a>, <a href="City%20of%20Bradford">Bradford</a>, <a href="Nottingham">Nottingham</a>, population size is not a prerequisite for city status. Traditionally the status was given to towns with <a href="List%20of%20cathedrals%20in%20England%20and%20Wales">diocesan cathedrals</a>, so there are smaller cities like <a href="Wells%2C%20Somerset">Wells</a>, <a href="Ely%2C%20Cambridgeshire">Ely</a>, <a href="Ripon">Ripon</a>, <a href="Truro">Truro</a> and <a href="Chichester">Chichester</a>.
Economy.
England's economy is one of the largest and most dynamic in the world, with an average <a href="GDP%20per%20capita">GDP per capita</a> of £28,100. <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Treasury">Her Majesty's Treasury</a>, led by the <a href="Chancellor%20of%20the%20Exchequer">Chancellor of the Exchequer</a>, is responsible for developing and executing the government's <a href="public%20finance">public finance</a> policy and <a href="economic%20policy">economic policy</a>. Usually regarded as a <a href="Anglo-Saxon%20economy">mixed market economy</a>, it has adopted many <a href="free%20market">free market</a> principles, yet maintains an advanced social welfare infrastructure. The official currency in England is the <a href="pound%20sterling">pound sterling</a>, whose <a href="ISO%204217">ISO 4217</a> code is GBP. <a href="Taxation%20in%20England">Taxation in England</a> is quite competitive when <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20tax%20rates">compared</a> to much of the rest of Europe – the basic rate of personal tax is 20% on taxable income up to £31,865 above the personal tax-free allowance (normally £10,000), and 40% on any additional earnings above that amount.
The economy of England is the largest part of the <a href="economy%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">UK's economy</a>, which has the <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20GDP%20%28PPP%29%20per%20capita">18th</a> highest GDP <a href="Purchasing%20power%20parity">PPP</a> per capita in the world. England is a leader in the chemical and pharmaceutical sectors and in key technical industries, particularly <a href="aerospace">aerospace</a>, the <a href="arms%20industry">arms industry</a>, and the manufacturing side of the <a href="software%20industry">software industry</a>. London, home to the <a href="London%20Stock%20Exchange">London Stock Exchange</a>, the United Kingdom's main <a href="stock%20exchange">stock exchange</a> and the largest in Europe, is England's financial centre, with 100 of Europe's 500 largest corporations being based there. London is the largest financial centre in Europe, and is the second largest in the world. <a href="Manchester">Manchester</a> is the largest financial and professional services sector outside London and is the mid tier private equity capital of Europe as well as one of the growing technology hubs of Europe. 
The <a href="Bank%20of%20England">Bank of England</a>, founded in 1694 by Scottish banker <a href="William%20Paterson%20%28banker%29">William Paterson</a>, is the United Kingdom's <a href="central%20bank">central bank</a>. Originally established as private banker to the government of England, since 1946 it has been a <a href="nationalisation">state-owned institution</a>. The bank has a monopoly on the issue of banknotes in <a href="England%20and%20Wales">England and Wales</a>, although not in other parts of the United Kingdom. The government has devolved responsibility to the bank's <a href="Monetary%20Policy%20Committee%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Monetary Policy Committee</a> for managing the monetary policy of the country and setting interest rates.
England is highly industrialised, but since the 1970s there has been a decline in traditional heavy and manufacturing industries, and an increasing emphasis on a more <a href="service%20industry">service industry</a> oriented economy. Tourism has become a significant industry, attracting millions of visitors to England each year. The export part of the economy is dominated by <a href="pharmaceuticals">pharmaceuticals</a>, cars (although many English <a href="marque">marque</a>s are now foreign-owned, such as <a href="Land%20Rover">Land Rover</a>, <a href="Lotus%20Cars">Lotus</a>, <a href="Jaguar%20Cars">Jaguar</a> and <a href="Bentley">Bentley</a>), <a href="crude%20oil">crude oil</a> and petroleum from the English parts of <a href="North%20Sea%20oil">North Sea oil</a> along with <a href="Wytch%20Farm">Wytch Farm</a>, <a href="aircraft%20engine">aircraft engine</a>s and alcoholic beverages. The <a href="creative%20industries">creative industries</a> accounted for 7 per cent GVA in 2005 and grew at an average of 6 per cent per annum between 1997 and 2005. 
Most of the UK's £30 billion <a href="Aerospace%20industry%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">aerospace industry</a> is primarily based in England. The global market opportunity for UK aerospace manufacturers over the next two decades is estimated at £3.5 trillion. <a href="GKN%20Aerospace">GKN Aerospace</a> – an expert in metallic and composite aerostructures is involved in almost every civil and military fixed and rotary wing aircraft in production is based in <a href="Redditch">Redditch</a>.
<a href="BAE%20Systems">BAE Systems</a> makes large sections of the <a href="Typhoon%20Eurofighter">Typhoon Eurofighter</a> at its sub-assembly plant in <a href="Samlesbury">Samlesbury</a> and assembles the aircraft for the RAF at its <a href="Warton%2C%20Fylde">Warton</a> plant, near <a href="Preston%2C%20Lancashire">Preston</a>. It is also a principal subcontractor on the <a href="F35%20Lightning%20II">F35 Joint Strike Fighter</a> – the world's largest single defence project – for which it designs and manufactures a range of components including the aft fuselage, vertical and horizontal tail and wing tips and fuel system. It also manufactures the <a href="BAE%20Systems%20Hawk">Hawk</a>, the world's most successful jet training aircraft.
<a href="Rolls-Royce%20Holdings">Rolls-Royce PLC</a> is the world's second-largest <a href="aircraft%20engine">aero-engine</a> manufacturer. Its engines power more than 30 types of commercial aircraft, and it has more 30,000 engines currently in service across both the civil and defence sectors. With a workforce of over 12,000 people, <a href="Derby">Derby</a> has the largest concentration of Rolls-Royce employees in the UK. Rolls-Royce also produces low-emission power systems for ships; makes critical equipment and safety systems for the nuclear industry and powers offshore platforms and major pipelines for the oil and gas industry. The <a href="Pharmaceutical%20industry%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">pharmaceutical industry</a> plays an important role in the economy, and the UK has the third-highest share of global pharmaceutical R&D expenditures.
Much of the UK's space industry is centred on <a href="EADS%20Astrium">EADS Astrium</a>, based in <a href="Stevenage">Stevenage</a> and <a href="Portsmouth">Portsmouth</a>. The company builds the <a href="Satellite%20bus">buses</a> – the underlying structure onto which the payload and propulsion systems are built – for most of the <a href="European%20Space%20Agency">European Space Agency</a>'s spacecraft, as well as commercial <a href="satellites">satellites</a>. The world leader in compact satellite systems, <a href="Surrey%20Satellite%20Technology">Surrey Satellite Technology</a>, is also part of Astrium. <a href="Reaction%20Engines%20Limited">Reaction Engines Limited</a>, the company planning to build <a href="Skylon%20%28spacecraft%29">Skylon</a>, a single-stage-to-orbit spaceplane using their <a href="SABRE%20%28rocket%20engine%29">SABRE rocket engine</a>, a combined-cycle, air-breathing rocket propulsion system is based <a href="Culham">Culham</a>. The UK space industry was worth £9.1bn in 2011 and employed 29,000 people. It is growing at a rate of 7.5 per cent annually, according to its umbrella organisation, the <a href="UK%20Space%20Agency">UK Space Agency</a>. In 2013, the British Government pledged £60 million to the <a href="Skylon%20%28spacecraft%29">Skylon</a> project: this investment will provide support at a "crucial stage" to allow a full-scale prototype of the <a href="SABRE%20%28rocket%20engine%29">SABRE</a> engine to be built.
Agriculture is intensive, highly mechanised and efficient by European standards, producing 60% of food needs with only 2% of the labour force. Two-thirds of production is devoted to livestock, the other to arable crops. The main crops that are grown are <a href="wheat">wheat</a>, <a href="barley">barley</a>, <a href="oat">oat</a>s, <a href="potato">potato</a>es, <a href="sugar%20beet">sugar beet</a>s. England retains a significant, though much reduced fishing industry. Its fleets bring home fish of every kind, ranging from <a href="Sole%20%28fish%29">sole</a> to <a href="herring">herring</a>. It is also rich in natural resources including <a href="coal">coal</a>, <a href="petroleum">petroleum</a>, <a href="natural%20gas">natural gas</a>, <a href="tin">tin</a>, <a href="limestone">limestone</a>, <a href="iron%20ore">iron ore</a>, <a href="salt">salt</a>, <a href="clay">clay</a>, <a href="chalk">chalk</a>, <a href="gypsum">gypsum</a>, <a href="lead">lead</a>, and silica.
Science and technology.
Prominent English figures from the field of science and mathematics include Sir <a href="Isaac%20Newton">Isaac Newton</a>, <a href="Michael%20Faraday">Michael Faraday</a>, <a href="Charles%20Darwin">Charles Darwin</a>, <a href="Robert%20Hooke">Robert Hooke</a>, <a href="James%20Prescott%20Joule">James Prescott Joule</a>, <a href="John%20Dalton">John Dalton</a>, <a href="Lord%20Rayleigh">Lord Rayleigh</a>, <a href="J.%20J.%20Thomson">J. J. Thomson</a>, <a href="James%20Chadwick">James Chadwick</a>, <a href="Charles%20Babbage">Charles Babbage</a>, <a href="George%20Boole">George Boole</a>, <a href="Alan%20Turing">Alan Turing</a>, <a href="Tim%20Berners-Lee">Tim Berners-Lee</a>, <a href="Paul%20Dirac">Paul Dirac</a>, <a href="Stephen%20Hawking">Stephen Hawking</a>, <a href="Peter%20Higgs">Peter Higgs</a>, <a href="Roger%20Penrose">Roger Penrose</a>, <a href="John%20Horton%20Conway">John Horton Conway</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Bayes">Thomas Bayes</a>, <a href="Arthur%20Cayley">Arthur Cayley</a>, <a href="G.%20H.%20Hardy">G. H. Hardy</a>, <a href="Oliver%20Heaviside">Oliver Heaviside</a>, <a href="Andrew%20Wiles">Andrew Wiles</a>, <a href="Edward%20Jenner">Edward Jenner</a>, <a href="Francis%20Crick">Francis Crick</a>, <a href="Joseph%20Lister%2C%201st%20Baron%20Lister">Joseph Lister</a>, <a href="Joseph%20Priestley">Joseph Priestley</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Young%20%28scientist%29">Thomas Young</a>, <a href="Christopher%20Wren">Christopher Wren</a> and <a href="Richard%20Dawkins">Richard Dawkins</a>. Some experts claim that the earliest concept of a <a href="metric%20system">metric system</a> was invented by <a href="John%20Wilkins">John Wilkins</a>, the first secretary of the <a href="Royal%20Society">Royal Society</a>, in 1668.
England was a leading centre of the <a href="Scientific%20Revolution">Scientific Revolution</a> from the 17th century. As the birthplace of the <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>, England was home to many significant inventors during the late 18th and early 19th centuries. Famous English engineers include <a href="Isambard%20Kingdom%20Brunel">Isambard Kingdom Brunel</a>, best known for the creation of the <a href="Great%20Western%20Railway">Great Western Railway</a>, a series of famous <a href="steamship">steamship</a>s, and numerous important bridges, hence revolutionising public transport and modern-day engineering. <a href="Thomas%20Newcomen">Thomas Newcomen</a>'s <a href="Newcomen%20steam%20engine">steam engine</a> helped spawn the Industrial Revolution. 
The Father of Railways, <a href="George%20Stephenson">George Stephenson</a>, built the first public inter-city railway line in the world, the <a href="Liverpool%20and%20Manchester%20Railway">Liverpool and Manchester Railway</a>, which opened in 1830. With his role in the marketing and manufacturing of the steam engine, and invention of modern coinage, <a href="Matthew%20Boulton">Matthew Boulton</a> (business partner of <a href="James%20Watt">James Watt</a>) is regarded as one of the most influential entrepreneurs in history. The physician <a href="Edward%20Jenner">Edward Jenner</a>'s <a href="smallpox%20vaccine">smallpox vaccine</a> is said to have "saved more lives ... than were lost in all the wars of mankind since the beginning of recorded history."
Inventions and discoveries of the English include: the <a href="jet%20engine">jet engine</a>, the first industrial <a href="spinning%20frame">spinning machine</a>, <a href="Analytical%20engine">the first computer</a> and the first <a href="Manchester%20Baby">modern computer</a>, the <a href="World%20Wide%20Web">World Wide Web</a> along with <a href="HTML">HTML</a>, the first successful human <a href="blood%20transfusion">blood transfusion</a>, the motorised <a href="vacuum%20cleaner">vacuum cleaner</a>, the <a href="lawn%20mower">lawn mower</a>, the <a href="seat%20belt">seat belt</a>, the <a href="hovercraft">hovercraft</a>, the <a href="electric%20motor">electric motor</a>, <a href="steam%20engine">steam engine</a>s, and theories such as the Darwinian theory of <a href="evolution">evolution</a> and <a href="atomic%20theory">atomic theory</a>. Newton developed the ideas of <a href="universal%20gravitation">universal gravitation</a>, <a href="Newtonian%20mechanics">Newtonian mechanics</a>, and <a href="calculus">calculus</a>, and <a href="Robert%20Hooke">Robert Hooke</a> his eponymously named <a href="Hooke%27s%20law%20of%20elasticity">law of elasticity</a>. Other inventions include the iron plate railway, the <a href="thermosiphon">thermosiphon</a>, <a href="Tarmacadam">tarmac</a>, the <a href="rubber%20band">rubber band</a>, the <a href="mousetrap">mousetrap</a>, <a href="Cat%27s%20eye%20%28road%29">"cat's eye"</a> <a href="raised%20pavement%20marker">road marker</a>, joint development of the <a href="light%20bulb">light bulb</a>, steam <a href="locomotive">locomotive</a>s, the modern <a href="seed%20drill">seed drill</a> and many modern techniques and technologies used in <a href="precision%20engineering">precision engineering</a>.
The <a href="Royal%20Society">Royal Society</a>, formally <a href="The%20Royal%20Society%20of%20London%20for%20Improving%20Natural%20Knowledge">The Royal Society of London for Improving Natural Knowledge</a>, is a <a href="learned%20society">learned society</a> and the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>'s national <a href="academy%20of%20sciences">academy of sciences</a>. Founded on 28 November 1660, it was granted a <a href="royal%20charter">royal charter</a> by <a href="Charles%20II%20of%20England">King Charles II</a> as "The Royal Society". It is the oldest national scientific institution in the world. The society fulfils a number of roles: promoting science and its benefits, recognising excellence in science, supporting outstanding science, providing scientific advice for policy, fostering international and global co-operation, education and public engagement.
The Royal Society started from groups of physicians and <a href="Natural%20philosopher">natural philosophers</a>, meeting at a variety of locations, including <a href="Gresham%20College">Gresham College</a> in London. They were influenced by the "<a href="Scientific%20method">new science</a>", as promoted by <a href="Francis%20Bacon">Francis Bacon</a> in his "<a href="New%20Atlantis">New Atlantis</a>", from approximately 1645 onwards. A group known as "The Philosophical Society of Oxford" was run under a set of rules still retained by the <a href="Bodleian%20Library">Bodleian Library</a>. After the <a href="English%20Restoration">English Restoration</a>, there were regular meetings at Gresham College. It is widely held that these groups were the inspiration for the foundation of the Royal Society. 
Scientific research and development remains important in the <a href="universities%20of%20England">universities of England</a>, with many establishing <a href="science%20park">science park</a>s to facilitate production and co-operation with industry. Between 2004 and 2008 the United Kingdom produced 7 per cent of the world's scientific research papers and had an 8 per cent share of scientific citations, the third and second-highest in the world (after the United States and China, respectively). Scientific journals produced in the United Kingdom include "<a href="Nature%20%28journal%29">Nature</a>", the "<a href="BMJ">British Medical Journal</a>" and "<a href="The%20Lancet">The Lancet</a>".
Transport.
The <a href="Department%20for%20Transport">Department for Transport</a> is the government body responsible for overseeing transport in England. The department is run by the <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Transport">Secretary of State for Transport</a>. 
England has a dense and modern transportation infrastructure. There are many <a href="List%20of%20motorways%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">motorways in England</a>, and many other trunk roads, such as the <a href="A1%20road%20%28Great%20Britain%29">A1 Great North Road</a>, which runs through eastern England from London to Newcastle (much of this section is motorway) and onward to the Scottish border. The longest motorway in England is the <a href="M6%20motorway">M6</a>, from <a href="Rugby%2C%20Warwickshire">Rugby</a> through the <a href="North%20West%20England">North West</a> up to the <a href="Anglo-Scottish%20border">Anglo-Scottish border</a>, a distance of . Other major routes include: the <a href="M1%20motorway">M1</a> from London to Leeds, the <a href="M25%20motorway">M25</a> which encircles London, the <a href="M60%20motorway%20%28Great%20Britain%29">M60</a> which encircles Manchester, the <a href="M4%20motorway">M4</a> from London to South Wales, the <a href="M62%20motorway">M62</a> from Liverpool via Manchester to East Yorkshire, and the <a href="M5%20motorway">M5</a> from Birmingham to Bristol and the South West.
Bus transport across the country is widespread; major companies include <a href="Arriva%20UK%20Bus">Arriva</a>, <a href="FirstGroup">FirstGroup</a>, <a href="Go-Ahead%20Group">Go-Ahead Group</a>, <a href="National%20Express">National Express</a>, <a href="Rotala">Rotala</a> and <a href="Stagecoach%20Group">Stagecoach Group</a>. The red <a href="double-decker%20bus">double-decker bus</a>es in London have become a symbol of England. 
<a href="National%20Cycle%20Route">National Cycle Route</a> offers cycling routes nationally. There is a <a href="rapid%20transit">rapid transit</a> network in two English cities: the <a href="London%20Underground">London Underground</a>; and the <a href="Tyne%20and%20Wear%20Metro">Tyne and Wear Metro</a> in <a href="Newcastle%20upon%20Tyne">Newcastle upon Tyne</a>, <a href="Gateshead">Gateshead</a> and <a href="Sunderland">Sunderland</a>. There are several tram networks, such as the <a href="Blackpool%20tramway">Blackpool tramway</a>, <a href="Manchester%20Metrolink">Manchester Metrolink</a>, <a href="Sheffield%20Supertram">Sheffield Supertram</a> and <a href="West%20Midlands%20Metro">West Midlands Metro</a>, and the <a href="Tramlink">Tramlink</a> system centred on Croydon in South London.
<a href="Great%20British%20Railways">Great British Railways</a> is a planned <a href="State%20ownership">state-owned</a> <a href="public%20body">public body</a> that will oversee <a href="rail%20transport%20in%20Great%20Britain">rail transport in Great Britain</a> from 2023. The <a href="Office%20of%20Rail%20and%20Road">Office of Rail and Road</a> is responsible for the economic and safety regulation of England's railways.
<a href="Rail%20transport%20in%20Great%20Britain">Rail transport in England</a> is the oldest in the world: passenger railways originated in England in 1825. Much of Britain's of rail network lies in England, covering the country fairly extensively, although a high proportion of railway lines were closed in the second half of the 20th century. There are plans to reopen lines such as the <a href="Varsity%20Line">Varsity Line</a> between Oxford and Cambridge. These lines are mostly standard gauge (<a href="single%20track%20%28rail%29">single</a>, <a href="double%20track">double</a> or <a href="quadruple%20track">quadruple track</a>) though there are also a few <a href="British%20narrow%20gauge%20railways">narrow gauge lines</a>. There is rail transport access to France and Belgium through an undersea rail link, the <a href="Channel%20Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a>, which was completed in 1994.
<a href="Crossrail">Crossrail</a>, under construction in London, is Europe's largest construction project with a £15 billion projected cost. <a href="High%20Speed%202">High Speed 2</a>, a new high-speed north–south railway line, projected in 2015 to cost £56 billion is to start being built in 2020.
England has extensive domestic and international aviation links. The largest airport is <a href="Heathrow%20Airport">Heathrow</a>, which is the <a href="World%27s%20busiest%20airports%20by%20international%20passenger%20traffic">world's busiest airport measured by number of international passengers</a>. Other large airports include <a href="Gatwick%20Airport">Gatwick</a>, <a href="Manchester%20Airport">Manchester</a>, <a href="Stansted%20Airport">Stansted</a>, <a href="Luton%20Airport">Luton</a> and <a href="Birmingham%20Airport">Birmingham</a>.
By sea there is ferry transport, both local and international, including from Liverpool to Ireland and the Isle of Man, and Hull to the Netherlands and Belgium. There are around of navigable waterways in England, half of which is owned by the <a href="Canal%20%26amp%3B%20River%20Trust">Canal & River Trust</a>, however, water transport is very limited. The <a href="River%20Thames">River Thames</a> is the major waterway in England, with imports and exports focused at the <a href="Port%20of%20Tilbury">Port of Tilbury</a> in the <a href="Thames%20Estuary">Thames Estuary</a>, one of the United Kingdom's three major ports.
Energy.
<a href="Energy">Energy</a> use in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> stood at 2,249 <a href="TWh">TWh</a> (193.4 million <a href="Tonne%20of%20oil%20equivalent">tonnes of oil equivalent</a>) in 2014. This equates to <a href="energy%20consumption">energy consumption</a> "<a href="per%20capita">per capita</a>" of 34.82 MWh (3.00 tonnes of oil equivalent) compared to a 2010 world average of 21.54 <a href="MWh">MWh</a> (1.85 <a href="tonne%20of%20oil%20equivalent">tonnes of oil equivalent</a>). Demand for electricity in 2014 was 34.42<a href="Watt">GW</a> on average (301.7TWh over the year) coming from a total electricity generation of 335.0<a href="Kilowatt%20hour">TWh</a>. 
Successive <a href="Government%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">UK governments</a> have outlined numerous commitments to reduce <a href="carbon%20dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> emissions. Notably, the UK is <a href="Wind%20power%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">one of the best sites in Europe for wind energy</a>, and wind power production is its fastest growing supply. Wind power contributed 15% of UK electricity generation in 2017. 
The <a href="Climate%20Change%20Act%202008">Climate Change Act 2008</a> was passed in <a href="Parliament">Parliament</a> with an overwhelming majority across political parties. It sets out emission reduction targets that the UK must comply with legally.
