It represents the first global legally binding climate change mitigation target set by a country. <a href="Energy%20policy%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">UK government energy policy</a> aims to play a key role in limiting <a href="greenhouse%20gas%20emissions">greenhouse gas emissions</a>, whilst meeting energy demand. Shifting availabilities of resources and development of technologies also change the country's <a href="energy%20mix">energy mix</a> through changes in costs.
The current energy policy is the responsibility of the <a href="Department%20for%20Business%2C%20Energy%20and%20Industrial%20Strategy">Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy</a> and <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Business%2C%20Energy%20and%20Industrial%20Strategy">Secretary of State for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy</a>. The <a href="Minister%20of%20State%20for%20Business%2C%20Energy%20and%20Clean%20Growth">Minister of State for Business, Energy and Clean Growth</a> is responsible for green finance, climate science and innovation, and low carbon generation. United Kingdom is ranked 4 out of 180 countries in the <a href="Environmental%20Performance%20Index">Environmental Performance Index</a>. A law has been passed that <a href="Greenhouse%20gas%20emissions">UK greenhouse gas emissions</a> will be <a href="net%20zero">net zero</a> by 2050.
Tourism.
<a href="English%20Heritage">English Heritage</a> is a governmental body with a broad remit of managing the historic sites, artefacts and environments of England. It is currently sponsored by the <a href="Department%20for%20Culture%2C%20Media%20and%20Sport">Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport</a>. 
The <a href="National%20Trust%20for%20Places%20of%20Historic%20Interest%20or%20Natural%20Beauty">National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty</a> is a charity which also maintains multiple sites. Of the 25 United Kingdom <a href="List%20of%20World%20Heritage%20Sites%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>, 17 are in England. 
Some of the best known of these include <a href="Stonehenge%2C%20Avebury%20and%20Associated%20Sites">Stonehenge, Avebury and Associated Sites</a>, <a href="Tower%20of%20London">Tower of London</a>, <a href="Jurassic%20Coast">Jurassic Coast</a>, <a href="Palace%20of%20Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>, <a href="Roman%20Baths%20%28Bath%29">Roman Baths</a>, <a href="Bath%2C%20Somerset">City of Bath</a>, <a href="Saltaire">Saltaire</a>, <a href="Ironbridge%20Gorge">Ironbridge Gorge</a>, <a href="Studley%20Royal%20Park">Studley Royal Park</a> and more recently the <a href="Lake%20District">English Lake District</a>. The northernmost point of the Roman Empire, <a href="Hadrian%27s%20Wall">Hadrian's Wall</a>, is the largest Roman artefact anywhere: it runs for a total of 73 miles in northern England.
The <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Digital%2C%20Culture%2C%20Media%20and%20Sport">Secretary of State for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport</a> has overall responsibility for tourism, arts and culture, cultural property, heritage and historic environments, libraries, and museums and galleries. The <a href="Parliamentary%20Under%20Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Arts%2C%20Heritage%20and%20Tourism">Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Arts, Heritage and Tourism</a> is the minister with responsibility over tourism in England. 
A <a href="blue%20plaque">blue plaque</a>, the oldest <a href="historical%20marker">historical marker</a> scheme in the world, is a permanent sign installed in a public place in England to commemorate a link between that location and a famous person or event. The scheme was the brainchild of politician <a href="William%20Ewart%20%28British%20politician%29">William Ewart</a> in 1863 and was initiated in 1866. It was formally established by the <a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Arts">Royal Society of Arts</a> in 1867, and since 1986 has been run by <a href="English%20Heritage">English Heritage</a>. In 2011 there were around 1,600 museums in England. Entry to most state-supported museums and galleries is free unlike in other countries. 
<a href="London">London</a> is one of the world's most visited cities, regularly taking the top five most visited cities in <a href="Europe">Europe</a>. It is largely considered a global centre of finance, arts and culture.
Healthcare.
The <a href="National%20Health%20Service%20%28England%29">National Health Service</a> (NHS), is the publicly funded <a href="healthcare%20system">healthcare system</a> responsible for providing the majority of healthcare in the country. The NHS began on 5 July 1948, putting into effect the provisions of the <a href="National%20Health%20Service%20Act%201946">National Health Service Act 1946</a>. It was based on the findings of the <a href="Beveridge%20Report">Beveridge Report</a>, prepared by economist and social reformer <a href="William%20Beveridge">William Beveridge</a>. The NHS is largely funded from general taxation including <a href="National%20Insurance">National Insurance</a> payments, and it provides most of its services free at the point of use, although there are charges for some people for eye tests, dental care, prescriptions and aspects of personal care.
The government department responsible for the NHS is the <a href="Department%20of%20Health%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Department of Health</a>, headed by the <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Health">Secretary of State for Health</a>, who sits in the <a href="Cabinet%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">British Cabinet</a>. Most of the expenditure of the Department of Health is spent on the NHS—£98.6 billion was spent in 2008–2009. In recent years the private sector has been increasingly used to provide more NHS services despite opposition by doctors and trade unions.
When purchasing drugs, the NHS has significant market power that, based on its own assessment of the fair value of the drugs, influences the global price, typically keeping prices lower. Several other countries either copy the UK's model or directly rely on Britain's assessments for their own decisions on state-financed drug reimbursements. Regulatory bodies such as the <a href="General%20Medical%20Council">General Medical Council</a> and the <a href="Nursing%20and%20Midwifery%20Council">Nursing and Midwifery Council</a> are organised on a UK-wide basis, as are non-governmental bodies such as the <a href="Royal%20College">Royal College</a>s.
The average <a href="life%20expectancy">life expectancy</a> of people in England is 77.5 years for males and 81.7 years for females, the highest of the four <a href="countries%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">countries of the United Kingdom</a>. The South of England has a higher life expectancy than the North; however, regional differences do seem to be slowly narrowing: between 1991–1993 and 2012–2014, life expectancy in the North East increased by 6.0 years and in the North West by 5.8 years, the fastest increase in any region outside London, and the gap between life expectancy in the North East and South East is now 2.5 years, down from 2.9 in 1993.
Demography.
Population.
With over 53 million inhabitants, England is by far the most populous country of the United Kingdom, accounting for 84% of the combined total. England taken as a unit and measured against international states would be the 25th largest <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20population%20in%202005">country by population</a> in the world.
The <a href="English%20people">English people</a> are <a href="British%20people">British people</a>. Some genetic evidence suggests that 75–95% descend in the paternal line from prehistoric settlers who originally came from the <a href="Iberian%20Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>, as well as a 5% contribution from <a href="Angles">Angles</a> and <a href="Saxons">Saxons</a>, and a significant Scandinavian (<a href="Vikings">Viking</a>) element. However, other geneticists place the <a href="Germanic%20peoples">Germanic</a> estimate up to half. Over time, various cultures have been influential: <a href="Prehistoric%20Britain">Prehistoric</a>, <a href="Britons%20%28historical%29">Brythonic</a>, <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Roman</a>, <a href="Anglo-Saxon">Anglo-Saxon</a>, <a href="Viking">Viking</a> (North Germanic), <a href="Gaels">Gaelic</a> cultures, as well as a large influence from <a href="Normans">Normans</a>. There is an English diaspora in former parts of the British Empire; especially the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>, <a href="Australia">Australia</a>, <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a> and <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. Since the late 1990s, many English people <a href="British%20migration%20to%20Spain">have migrated</a> to Spain.
In 1086, when the "<a href="Domesday%20Book">Domesday Book</a>" was compiled, England had a population of two million. About 10% lived in urban areas. By 1801, the population was 8.3 million, and by 1901 30.5 million. Due in particular to the economic prosperity of <a href="South%20East%20England">South East England</a>, it has received many economic migrants from the other parts of the United Kingdom. There has been <a href="Irish%20migration%20to%20Great%20Britain">significant Irish migration</a>. The proportion of ethnically European residents totals at 87.50%, including <a href="British%20Germans">Germans</a> and <a href="Polish%20British">Poles</a>.
Other people from much further afield in the former British colonies have arrived since the 1950s: in particular, 6% of people living in England have family origins in the <a href="Indian%20subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>, mostly <a href="India">India</a>, <a href="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> and <a href="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>. About 0.7% of people are Chinese. 2.90% of the population are black, from Africa and the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, especially former British colonies. In 2007, 22% of primary school children in England were from <a href="minority%20group">ethnic minority</a> families, and in 2011 that figure was 26.5%. About half of the population increase between 1991 and 2001 was due to immigration. Debate over immigration is politically prominent; 80% of respondents in a 2009 <a href="Home%20Office">Home Office</a> poll wanted to cap it. The <a href="Office%20for%20National%20Statistics">ONS</a> has projected that the population will grow by nine million between 2014 and 2039.
England contains one indigenous national minority, the <a href="Cornish%20people">Cornish people</a>, recognised by the UK government under the <a href="Framework%20Convention%20for%20the%20Protection%20of%20National%20Minorities">Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities</a> in 2014.
Language.
As its name suggests, the <a href="English%20language">English language</a>, today spoken by hundreds of millions of people around the world, originated as the language of England, where it remains the principal tongue spoken by 98% of the population. It is an <a href="Indo-European%20languages">Indo-European</a> language in the <a href="Anglo-Frisian%20languages">Anglo-Frisian</a> branch of the <a href="Germanic%20languages">Germanic</a> family. After the <a href="Norman%20conquest">Norman conquest</a>, the <a href="Old%20English">Old English</a> language, brought to Britain by the <a href="Anglo-Saxons">Anglo-Saxon settlers</a>, was confined to the <a href="Working%20class">lower social classes</a> as <a href="Norman%20language">Norman French</a> and <a href="Latin">Latin</a> were used by the aristocracy.
By the 15th century, English was back in fashion among all classes, though much changed; the <a href="Middle%20English">Middle English</a> form showed many signs of French influence, both in vocabulary and spelling. During the <a href="English%20Renaissance">English Renaissance</a>, many words were coined from Latin and Greek origins. <a href="Modern%20English">Modern English</a> has extended this custom of flexibility when it comes to incorporating words from different languages. Thanks in large part to the <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a>, the English language is the world's unofficial "<a href="lingua%20franca">lingua franca</a>".
<a href="English%20as%20a%20second%20or%20foreign%20language">English language learning and teaching</a> is an important <a href="Economics">economic activity</a>, and includes <a href="language%20schools">language schooling</a>, tourism spending, and publishing. There is no <a href="United%20Kingdom%20legislation">legislation</a> mandating an <a href="official%20language">official language</a> for England, but English is the only language used for official business. Despite the country's relatively small size, there are many distinct <a href="Regional%20accents%20of%20English%20speakers%23England">regional accents</a>, and individuals with particularly strong accents may not be easily understood everywhere in the country.
As well as English, England has two other <a href="indigenous%20language">indigenous language</a>s, <a href="Cornish%20language">Cornish</a> and <a href="Welsh%20language">Welsh</a>. Cornish died out as a community language in the 18th century but is being revived, and is now protected under the <a href="European%20Charter%20for%20Regional%20or%20Minority%20Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a>. It is spoken by 0.1% of people in <a href="Cornwall">Cornwall</a>, and is taught to some degree in several primary and secondary schools.
When the modern border between Wales and England was established by the <a href="Laws%20in%20Wales%20Acts%201535%20and%201542">Laws in Wales Acts 1535 and 1542</a>, many Welsh-speaking communities found themselves on the English side of the border. Welsh was spoken in <a href="Archenfield">Archenfield</a> in Herefordshire into the nineteenth century, and by natives of parts of western <a href="Shropshire">Shropshire</a> until the middle of the twentieth century if not later.
<a href="State%20school">State school</a>s teach students a <a href="second%20language">second language</a> or <a href="third%20language">third language</a> from the ages of seven, most commonly French, Spanish or German. It was reported in 2007 that around 800,000 school students spoke a <a href="foreign%20language">foreign language</a> at home as a result of immigration among their family, the most common languages being <a href="Punjabi%20language">Punjabi</a> and <a href="Urdu">Urdu</a>. However, following the 2011 census data released by the <a href="Office%20for%20National%20Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a>, figures now show that Polish is the main language spoken in England after English.
Religion.
In the 2011 census, 59.4% of the population of England specified their religion as Christian, 24.7% answered that they had no religion, 5% specified that they were <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a>, while 3.7% of the population belongs to other religions and 7.2% did not give an answer. Christianity is the most widely practised religion in England, as it has been since the Early Middle Ages, although it was first introduced much earlier in Gaelic and Roman times. This <a href="Celtic%20Church">Celtic Church</a> was gradually joined to the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Catholic</a> hierarchy following the 6th-century <a href="Gregorian%20mission">Gregorian mission</a> to <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Kent">Kent</a> led by <a href="Augustine%20of%20Canterbury">St Augustine</a>. The <a href="established%20church">established church</a> of England is the <a href="Church%20of%20England">Church of England</a>, which left communion with <a href="Vatican%20City">Rome</a> in the 1530s when <a href="Henry%20VIII%20of%20England">Henry VIII</a> was unable to annul his marriage to <a href="Catherine%20of%20Aragon">the aunt</a> of the <a href="Charles%20V%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">king of Spain</a>. The church regards itself as both Catholic and <a href="Protestant">Protestant</a>.
There are <a href="High%20Church">High Church</a> and <a href="Low%20Church">Low Church</a> traditions and some Anglicans regard themselves as <a href="Anglo-Catholics">Anglo-Catholics</a>, following the <a href="Tractarian%20movement">Tractarian movement</a>. The monarch of the United Kingdom is the <a href="Supreme%20Governor%20of%20the%20Church%20of%20England">Supreme Governor of the Church of England</a>, which has around 26 million baptised members (of whom the vast majority are not regular churchgoers). It forms part of the <a href="Anglican%20Communion">Anglican Communion</a> with the <a href="Archbishop%20of%20Canterbury">Archbishop of Canterbury</a> acting as its symbolic worldwide head. Many <a href="List%20of%20cathedrals%20in%20England%20and%20Wales">cathedrals</a> and parish churches are historic buildings of significant architectural importance, such as <a href="Westminster%20Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>, <a href="York%20Minster">York Minster</a>, <a href="Durham%20Cathedral">Durham Cathedral</a>, and <a href="Salisbury%20Cathedral">Salisbury Cathedral</a>.
The 2nd-largest Christian practice is the <a href="Latin%20Rite">Latin Rite</a> of the Catholic Church. Since its reintroduction after the <a href="Catholic%20Emancipation">Catholic Emancipation</a>, the Church has organised ecclesiastically on an <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church%20in%20England%20and%20Wales">England and Wales</a> basis where there are 4.5 million members (most of whom are English). There has been one Pope from England to date, <a href="Pope%20Adrian%20IV">Adrian IV</a>; while saints <a href="Bede">Bede</a> and <a href="Anselm%20of%20Canterbury">Anselm</a> are regarded as <a href="Doctors%20of%20the%20Church">Doctors of the Church</a>.
A form of <a href="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> known as <a href="Methodist%20Church%20of%20Great%20Britain">Methodism</a> is the third largest Christian practice and grew out of Anglicanism through <a href="John%20Wesley">John Wesley</a>. It gained popularity in the <a href="mill%20town">mill town</a>s of <a href="Lancashire">Lancashire</a> and <a href="Yorkshire">Yorkshire</a>, and amongst tin miners in <a href="Cornwall">Cornwall</a>. There are other <a href="Nonconformist%20%28Protestantism%29">non-conformist</a> minorities, such as <a href="Baptists">Baptists</a>, <a href="Quakers">Quakers</a>, <a href="Congregational%20church">Congregationalists</a>, <a href="Unitarianism">Unitarians</a> and <a href="The%20Salvation%20Army">The Salvation Army</a>.
The patron saint of England is <a href="Saint%20George">Saint George</a>; his symbolic cross is included in the flag of England, as well as in the Union Flag as part of a combination. There are many other English and associated saints; some of the best-known are: <a href="Cuthbert">Cuthbert</a>, <a href="Edmund%20the%20Martyr">Edmund</a>, <a href="Saint%20Alban">Alban</a>, <a href="Wilfrid">Wilfrid</a>, <a href="Aidan%20of%20Lindisfarne">Aidan</a>, <a href="Edward%20the%20Confessor">Edward the Confessor</a>, <a href="John%20Fisher">John Fisher</a>, <a href="Thomas%20More">Thomas More</a>, <a href="Saint%20Petroc">Petroc</a>, <a href="Saint%20Piran">Piran</a>, <a href="Margaret%20Clitherow">Margaret Clitherow</a> and <a href="Thomas%20Becket">Thomas Becket</a>. There are non-Christian religions practised. <a href="Jews">Jews</a> have a history of a small minority on the island since 1070. They were expelled from England in 1290 following the <a href="Edict%20of%20Expulsion">Edict of Expulsion</a>, only to be allowed back in 1656.
Especially since the 1950s, religions from the <a href="British%20Empire">former British colonies</a> have grown in numbers, due to immigration. <a href="Islam">Islam</a> is the most common of these, now accounting for around 5% of the population in England. <a href="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, <a href="Sikhism">Sikhism</a> and <a href="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> are next in number, adding up to 2.8% combined, introduced from India and <a href="South%20East%20Asia">South East Asia</a>.
A small minority of the population practise ancient <a href="Pagan%20religion">Pagan religion</a>s. <a href="Neopaganism%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Neopaganism in the United Kingdom</a> is primarily represented by <a href="Wicca">Wicca</a> and <a href="Contemporary%20Witchcraft">Witchcraft religions</a>, <a href="Neo-Druidry">Druidry</a>, and <a href="Germanic%20neopaganism">Heathenry</a>. According to the <a href="United%20Kingdom%20Census%202011">2011 UK Census</a>, there are roughly 53,172 people who identify as Pagan in England, and 3,448 in <a href="Wales">Wales</a>, including 11,026 <a href="Wicca">Wicca</a>ns in England and 740 in Wales.
24.7% of people in England declared <a href="Irreligion">no religion</a> in 2011, compared with 14.6% in 2001. These figures are slightly lower than the combined figures for England and Wales as Wales has a higher level of irreligion than England. <a href="Norwich">Norwich</a> had the highest such proportion at 42.5%, followed closely by <a href="Brighton%20and%20Hove">Brighton and Hove</a> at 42.4%.
Education.
The <a href="Department%20for%20Education">Department for Education</a> is the government department responsible for issues affecting people in England up to the age of 19, including education. State-run and state-funded schools are attended by approximately 93% of English schoolchildren. Education is the responsibility of the <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Education">Secretary of State for Education</a>.
Children who are between the ages of 3 and 5 attend nursery or an <a href="Early%20Years%20Foundation%20Stage">Early Years Foundation Stage</a> reception unit within a primary school. Children between the ages of 5 and 11 attend primary school, and secondary school is attended by those aged between 11 and 16. State-funded schools are obliged by law to teach the <a href="National%20Curriculum%20for%20England">National Curriculum</a>; basic areas of learning include English literature, English language, mathematics, science, art & design, citizenship, history, geography, religious education, design & technology, computing, ancient & modern languages, music, and physical education.
More than 90% of English schools require students to wear uniforms. School uniforms are defined by individual schools, within the constraint that uniform regulations must not discriminate on the grounds of sex, race, disability, sexual orientation, gender reassignment, religion or belief. Schools may choose to permit trousers for girls or religious dress.
The <a href="Programme%20for%20International%20Student%20Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a> coordinated by the <a href="OECD">OECD</a> currently ranks the overall knowledge and skills of British 15-year-olds as 13th in the world in reading literacy, mathematics, and science with the average British student scoring 503.7, compared with the OECD average of 493, ahead of the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> and most of <a href="Europe">Europe</a>.
Although most English secondary schools are <a href="comprehensive%20school">comprehensive</a>, there are selective intake <a href="grammar%20school">grammar school</a>s to which entrance is subject to passing the <a href="eleven-plus">eleven-plus</a> exam. Around 7.2 per cent of English schoolchildren attend <a href="Independent%20school%20%28UK%29">private schools</a>, which are funded by private sources. Standards in state schools are monitored by the <a href="Office%20for%20Standards%20in%20Education">Office for Standards in Education</a>, and in private schools by the <a href="Independent%20Schools%20Inspectorate">Independent Schools Inspectorate</a>.
After finishing compulsory education, students take <a href="General%20Certificate%20of%20Secondary%20Education">GCSE</a> examinations. Students may then opt to continue into <a href="further%20education">further education</a> for two years. <a href="List%20of%20further%20education%20colleges%20in%20England">Further education colleges</a> (particularly <a href="sixth%20form%20colleges">sixth form colleges</a>) often form part of a secondary school site. <a href="A-level">A-level</a> examinations are sat by a large number of further education students, and often form the basis of an application to university. Further education (FE) covers a wide curriculum of study and <a href="apprenticeship">apprenticeship</a>s, including <a href="T%20Level">T-levels</a>, <a href="BTEC%20Extended%20Diploma">BTEC</a>, <a href="NVQ">NVQ</a> and others. <a href="Tertiary%20college">Tertiary college</a>s provide both academic and vocational courses.
Higher education students normally attend university from age 18 onwards, where they study for an <a href="academic%20degree">academic degree</a>. There are over 90 universities in England, all but one of which are <a href="Public%20university">public institutions</a>. The <a href="Department%20for%20Business%2C%20Innovation%20and%20Skills">Department for Business, Innovation and Skills</a> is the government department responsible for higher education in England. Students are generally entitled to <a href="student%20loan">student loan</a>s to cover the cost of <a href="tuition%20fees">tuition fees</a> and living costs. The first degree offered to undergraduates is the <a href="bachelor%27s%20degree">bachelor's degree</a>, which usually takes three years to complete. Students are then able to work towards a postgraduate degree, which usually takes one year, or towards a doctorate, which takes three or more years.
<a href="List%20of%20universities%20in%20England">England's universities</a> include some of the highest-ranked universities in the world; <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a>, <a href="University%20of%20Oxford">University of Oxford</a>, <a href="Imperial%20College%20London">Imperial College London</a>, <a href="University%20College%20London">University College London</a> and <a href="King%27s%20College%20London">King's College London</a> are all ranked in the global top 30 in the 2018 "<a href="QS%20World%20University%20Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a>". The <a href="London%20School%20of%20Economics">London School of Economics</a> has been described as the world's leading social science institution for both teaching and research. The <a href="London%20Business%20School">London Business School</a> is considered one of the world's leading business schools and in 2010 its MBA programme was ranked best in the world by the "<a href="Financial%20Times">Financial Times</a>". <a href="Academic%20degree">Academic degree</a>s in England are usually split into classes: first class (1st), upper second class (2:1), lower second class (2:2), third (3rd), and unclassified.
<a href="The%20King%27s%20School%2C%20Canterbury">The King's School, Canterbury</a> and <a href="King%27s%20School%2C%20Rochester">King's School, Rochester</a> are the oldest schools in the English-speaking world. Many of England's most well-known schools, such as <a href="Winchester%20College">Winchester College</a>, <a href="Eton%20College">Eton</a>, <a href="St%20Paul%27s%20School%20%28London%29">St Paul's School</a>, <a href="Harrow%20School">Harrow School</a> and <a href="Rugby%20School">Rugby School</a> are fee-paying institutions.
Culture.
Architecture.
Many ancient <a href="standing%20stone">standing stone</a> monuments were erected during the prehistoric period; amongst the best known are <a href="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a>, <a href="Devil%27s%20Arrows">Devil's Arrows</a>, <a href="Rudston%20Monolith">Rudston Monolith</a> and <a href="Castlerigg%20stone%20circle">Castlerigg</a>. With the introduction of <a href="Ancient%20Roman%20architecture">Ancient Roman architecture</a> there was a development of <a href="basilicas">basilicas</a>, <a href="Roman%20baths">baths</a>, <a href="amphitheaters">amphitheaters</a>, <a href="triumphal%20arch">triumphal arch</a>es, <a href="villa">villa</a>s, <a href="Roman%20temple">Roman temple</a>s, <a href="Roman%20road">Roman road</a>s, <a href="Roman%20fort">Roman fort</a>s, <a href="stockade">stockade</a>s and <a href="aqueduct%20%28bridge%29">aqueducts</a>. It was the Romans who founded the first cities and towns such as London, Bath, York, Chester and St Albans. Perhaps the best-known example is <a href="Hadrian%27s%20Wall">Hadrian's Wall</a> stretching right across northern England. Another well-preserved example is the <a href="Roman%20Baths%20%28Bath%29">Roman Baths</a> at <a href="Bath%2C%20Somerset">Bath, Somerset</a>.
<a href="Anglo-Saxon%20architecture">Early Medieval architecture's</a> secular buildings were simple constructions mainly using timber with <a href="thatch">thatch</a> for roofing. Ecclesiastical architecture ranged from a synthesis of <a href="Early%20Christian%20Ireland">Hiberno</a>–<a href="Germanic%20Christianity">Saxon</a> <a href="monasticism">monasticism</a>, to <a href="Early%20Christian%20art%20and%20architecture">Early Christian</a> <a href="basilica">basilica</a> and architecture characterised by pilaster-strips, blank arcading, baluster shafts and triangular headed openings. After the Norman conquest in 1066 various <a href="Castles%20in%20England">Castles in England</a> were created so law lords could uphold their authority and in the north to protect from invasion. Some of the best-known medieval castles are the <a href="Tower%20of%20London">Tower of London</a>, <a href="Warwick%20Castle">Warwick Castle</a>, <a href="Durham%20Castle">Durham Castle</a> and <a href="Windsor%20Castle">Windsor Castle</a>.
Throughout the Plantagenet era, an <a href="English%20Gothic%20architecture">English Gothic architecture</a> flourished, with prime examples including the <a href="Architecture%20of%20the%20medieval%20cathedrals%20of%20England">medieval cathedrals</a> such as <a href="Canterbury%20Cathedral">Canterbury Cathedral</a>, <a href="Westminster%20Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a> and <a href="York%20Minster">York Minster</a>. Expanding on the <a href="Norman%20architecture">Norman base</a> there was also <a href="castle">castle</a>s, <a href="palace">palace</a>s, <a href="List%20of%20historic%20houses%20in%20England">great houses</a>, universities and <a href="parish%20church">parish church</a>es. Medieval architecture was completed with the 16th-century <a href="Tudor%20architecture">Tudor style</a>; the four-centred arch, now known as the <a href="Tudor%20arch">Tudor arch</a>, was a defining feature as were <a href="wattle%20and%20daub">wattle and daub</a> houses domestically. In the aftermath of the <a href="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> a form of architecture echoing classical antiquity synthesised with Christianity appeared, the <a href="English%20Baroque">English Baroque</a> style of architect <a href="Christopher%20Wren">Christopher Wren</a> being particularly championed.
<a href="Georgian%20architecture">Georgian architecture</a> followed in a more refined style, evoking a simple Palladian form; the <a href="Royal%20Crescent">Royal Crescent</a> at Bath is one of the best examples of this. With the emergence of <a href="romanticism">romanticism</a> during Victorian period, a <a href="Gothic%20Revival">Gothic Revival</a> was launched. In addition to this, around the same time the Industrial Revolution paved the way for buildings such as <a href="The%20Crystal%20Palace">The Crystal Palace</a>. Since the 1930s various <a href="modernist%20architecture">modernist</a> forms have appeared whose reception is often controversial, though traditionalist resistance movements continue with support in influential places.
Gardens.
Landscape gardening, as developed by <a href="Capability%20Brown">Capability Brown</a>, set an international trend for the <a href="English%20garden">English garden</a>. Gardening, and visiting gardens, are regarded as typically English pursuits. The English garden presented an idealized view of nature. At large country houses, the English garden usually included lakes, sweeps of gently rolling lawns set against groves of trees, and recreations of classical temples, <a href="Gothic%20architecture">Gothic</a> ruins, bridges, and other picturesque architecture, designed to recreate an idyllic pastoral landscape.
By the end of the 18th century, the English garden was being imitated by the <a href="French%20landscape%20garden">French landscape garden</a>, and as far away as St. Petersburg, Russia, in <a href="Pavlovsk%2C%20Saint%20Petersburg">Pavlovsk</a>, the gardens of the future <a href="Emperor%20Paul">Emperor Paul</a>. It also had a major influence on the form of the <a href="public%20parks">public parks</a> and gardens which appeared around the world in the 19th century. The English landscape garden was centred on the <a href="English%20country%20house">English country house</a> and manor houses. 
<a href="English%20Heritage">English Heritage</a> and the <a href="National%20Trust">National Trust</a> preserve great gardens and landscape parks throughout the country. The <a href="RHS%20Chelsea%20Flower%20Show">RHS Chelsea Flower Show</a> is held every year by the <a href="Royal%20Horticultural%20Society">Royal Horticultural Society</a> and is said to be the largest gardening show in the world.
Folklore.
English folklore developed over many centuries. Some of the characters and stories are present across England, but most belong to specific regions. Common folkloric beings include <a href="pixie">pixie</a>s, <a href="giant%20%28mythology%29">giants</a>, <a href="elf">elves</a>, <a href="bogeymen">bogeymen</a>, <a href="troll">troll</a>s, <a href="goblin">goblin</a>s and <a href="dwarf%20%28mythology%29">dwarves</a>. While many legends and folk-customs are thought to be ancient, such as the tales featuring <a href="Offa%20of%20Angel">Offa of Angel</a> and <a href="Wayland%20the%20Smith">Wayland the Smith</a>, others date from after the Norman invasion. The legends featuring <a href="Robin%20Hood">Robin Hood</a> and his <a href="Merry%20Men">Merry Men</a> of <a href="Sherwood%20Forest">Sherwood</a>, and their battles with the <a href="Sheriff%20of%20Nottingham">Sheriff of Nottingham</a>, are among the best-known of these.
During the <a href="High%20Middle%20Ages">High Middle Ages</a> tales originating from Brythonic traditions entered English folklore and developed into the <a href="Arthurian%20myth">Arthurian myth</a>. These were derived from <a href="Anglo-Norman%20language">Anglo-Norman</a>, Welsh and French sources, featuring <a href="King%20Arthur">King Arthur</a>, <a href="Camelot">Camelot</a>, <a href="Excalibur">Excalibur</a>, <a href="Merlin">Merlin</a> and the <a href="Knights%20of%20the%20Round%20Table">Knights of the Round Table</a> such as <a href="Lancelot">Lancelot</a>. These stories are most centrally brought together within <a href="Geoffrey%20of%20Monmouth">Geoffrey of Monmouth</a>'s "<a href="Historia%20Regum%20Britanniae">Historia Regum Britanniae</a>" ("History of the Kings of Britain"). Another early figure from <a href="Britons%20%28historic%29">British tradition</a>, <a href="King%20Cole">King Cole</a>, may have been based on a real figure from Sub-Roman Britain. Many of the tales and <a href="pseudohistory">pseudo-histories</a> make up part of the wider <a href="Matter%20of%20Britain">Matter of Britain</a>, a collection of shared British folklore.
Some folk figures are based on semi or actual historical people whose story has been passed down centuries; <a href="Lady%20Godiva">Lady Godiva</a> for instance was said to have ridden naked on horseback through <a href="Coventry">Coventry</a>, <a href="Hereward%20the%20Wake">Hereward the Wake</a> was a heroic English figure resisting the Norman invasion, <a href="Herne%20the%20Hunter">Herne the Hunter</a> is an <a href="equestrianism">equestrian</a> ghost associated with <a href="Windsor%2C%20Berkshire">Windsor</a> Forest and <a href="Windsor%20Great%20Park">Great Park</a> and <a href="Mother%20Shipton">Mother Shipton</a> is the archetypal witch. On 5 November people make bonfires, set off <a href="fireworks">fireworks</a> and eat <a href="toffee%20apple">toffee apple</a>s in <a href="Guy%20Fawkes%20Night">commemoration</a> of the foiling of the <a href="Gunpowder%20Plot">Gunpowder Plot</a> centred on <a href="Guy%20Fawkes">Guy Fawkes</a>. The chivalrous bandit, such as <a href="Dick%20Turpin">Dick Turpin</a>, is a recurring character, while <a href="Blackbeard">Blackbeard</a> is the archetypal pirate. There are various national and regional folk activities, participated in to this day, such as <a href="Morris%20dancing">Morris dancing</a>, <a href="Maypole%20dance">Maypole dancing</a>, <a href="Rapper%20sword">Rapper sword</a> in the North East, <a href="Long%20Sword%20dance">Long Sword dance</a> in Yorkshire, <a href="Mummers%20Play">Mummers Play</a>s, <a href="bottle-kicking">bottle-kicking</a> in Leicestershire, and <a href="Cooper%27s%20Hill%20Cheese-Rolling%20and%20Wake">cheese-rolling</a> at <a href="Brockworth%2C%20Gloucestershire">Cooper's Hill</a>. There is no official national costume, but a few are well established such as the <a href="Pearly%20Kings%20and%20Queens">Pearly Kings and Queens</a> associated with cockneys, the <a href="Queen%27s%20Guard">Royal Guard</a>, the <a href="Morris%20dance">Morris costume</a> and <a href="Beefeater">Beefeater</a>s.
Cuisine.
Since the <a href="early%20modern%20period">early modern period</a> the food of England has historically been characterised by its simplicity of approach and a reliance on the high quality of natural produce. During the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a> and through the Renaissance period, English cuisine enjoyed an excellent reputation, though a decline began during the <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> with the move away from the land and increasing urbanisation of the populace. The cuisine of England has, however, recently undergone a revival, which has been recognised by food critics with some good ratings in "<a href="Restaurant%20%28magazine%29">Restaurant</a>"s <a href="best%20restaurant%20in%20the%20world">best restaurant in the world</a> charts. An early book of English recipes is the "<a href="Forme%20of%20Cury">Forme of Cury</a>" from the royal court of <a href="Richard%20II%20of%20England">Richard II</a>.
Traditional examples of English food include the <a href="Sunday%20roast">Sunday roast</a>, featuring a <a href="roasting">roasted joint</a> (usually beef, <a href="lamb%20and%20mutton">lamb</a>, chicken or pork) served with assorted vegetables, <a href="Yorkshire%20pudding">Yorkshire pudding</a> and <a href="gravy">gravy</a>. Other prominent meals include <a href="fish%20and%20chips">fish and chips</a> and the <a href="Full%20breakfast">full English breakfast</a> (generally consisting of <a href="bacon">bacon</a>, <a href="sausages">sausages</a>, grilled tomatoes, fried bread, <a href="black%20pudding">black pudding</a>, <a href="baked%20beans">baked beans</a>, <a href="edible%20mushroom">mushrooms</a> and eggs). Various <a href="meat%20pie">meat pie</a>s are consumed, such as <a href="steak%20and%20kidney%20pie">steak and kidney pie</a>, <a href="steak%20and%20ale%20pie">steak and ale pie</a>, <a href="cottage%20pie">cottage pie</a>, <a href="pork%20pie">pork pie</a> (usually eaten cold) and the <a href="Cornish%20pasty">Cornish pasty</a>.
Sausages are commonly eaten, either as <a href="bangers%20and%20mash">bangers and mash</a> or <a href="toad%20in%20the%20hole">toad in the hole</a>. <a href="Lancashire%20hotpot">Lancashire hotpot</a> is a well-known stew originating in the northwest. Some of the more popular cheeses are <a href="Cheddar%20cheese">Cheddar</a>, <a href="Red%20Leicester">Red Leicester</a>, <a href="Wensleydale%20%28cheese%29">Wensleydale</a>, <a href="Double%20Gloucester">Double Gloucester</a> and <a href="Stilton%20cheese">Blue Stilton</a>. Many <a href="Anglo-Indian">Anglo-Indian</a> hybrid dishes, <a href="curries">curries</a>, have been created, such as <a href="chicken%20tikka%20masala">chicken tikka masala</a> and <a href="balti%20%28food%29">balti</a>. Traditional English dessert dishes include <a href="apple%20pie">apple pie</a> or other fruit pies; <a href="spotted%20dick">spotted dick</a> – all generally served with <a href="custard">custard</a>; and, more recently, <a href="sticky%20toffee%20pudding">sticky toffee pudding</a>. Sweet pastries include <a href="scones">scones</a> (either plain or containing dried fruit) served with jam or cream, dried fruit loaves, <a href="Eccles%20cake">Eccles cake</a>s and <a href="mince%20pie">mince pie</a>s as well as a wide range of sweet or spiced biscuits.
Common non-alcoholic drinks include tea, the popularity of which was increased by <a href="Catherine%20of%20Braganza">Catherine of Braganza</a>, and coffee; frequently consumed alcoholic drinks include wine, <a href="cider">cider</a>s and <a href="English%20beer">English beer</a>s, such as <a href="bitter%20%28beer%29">bitter</a>, <a href="mild%20ale">mild</a>, <a href="stout">stout</a> and <a href="brown%20ale">brown ale</a>.
Visual arts.
The earliest known examples are the prehistoric rock and <a href="cave%20art">cave art</a> pieces, most prominent in <a href="North%20Yorkshire">North Yorkshire</a>, Northumberland and <a href="Cumbria">Cumbria</a>, but also feature further south, for example at <a href="Creswell%20Crags">Creswell Crags</a>. With the arrival of <a href="Roman%20culture">Roman culture</a> in the 1st century, various forms of art such as statues, busts, glasswork and mosaics were the norm. There are numerous surviving artefacts, such as those at <a href="Lullingstone%20Roman%20Villa">Lullingstone</a> and <a href="Isurium%20Brigantum">Aldborough</a>. During the Early Middle Ages the style favoured sculpted crosses and ivories, manuscript painting, gold and enamel jewellery, demonstrating a love of intricate, interwoven designs such as in the <a href="Staffordshire%20Hoard">Staffordshire Hoard</a> discovered in 2009. Some of these blended <a href="Insular%20art">Gaelic and Anglian</a> styles, such as the <a href="Lindisfarne%20Gospels">Lindisfarne Gospels</a> and <a href="Vespasian%20Psalter">Vespasian Psalter</a>. Later <a href="Gothic%20art">Gothic art</a> was popular at Winchester and Canterbury, examples survive such as <a href="Benedictional%20of%20St.%20%C3%86thelwold">Benedictional of St. Æthelwold</a> and <a href="Luttrell%20Psalter">Luttrell Psalter</a>.
The Tudor era saw <a href="Artists%20of%20the%20Tudor%20court">prominent artists</a> as part of their court, portrait painting which would remain an enduring part of English art, was boosted by German <a href="Hans%20Holbein%20the%20Younger">Hans Holbein</a>, natives such as <a href="Nicholas%20Hilliard">Nicholas Hilliard</a> built on this. Under the Stuarts, Continental artists were influential especially the Flemish, examples from the period include <a href="Anthony%20van%20Dyck">Anthony van Dyck</a>, <a href="Peter%20Lely">Peter Lely</a>, <a href="Godfrey%20Kneller">Godfrey Kneller</a> and <a href="William%20Dobson">William Dobson</a>. The 18th century was a time of significance with the founding of the <a href="Royal%20Academy">Royal Academy</a>, a <a href="classicism">classicism</a> based on the <a href="Renaissance%20art">High Renaissance</a> prevailed, with <a href="Thomas%20Gainsborough">Thomas Gainsborough</a> and <a href="Joshua%20Reynolds">Joshua Reynolds</a> becoming two of England's most treasured artists.
In the 19th century, <a href="John%20Constable">Constable</a> and <a href="J.M.W.%20Turner">Turner</a> were major landscape artists. The <a href="Norwich%20School%20%28art%20movement%29">Norwich School</a> continued the landscape tradition, while the <a href="Pre-Raphaelite%20Brotherhood">Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood</a>, led by artists such as <a href="Holman%20Hunt">Holman Hunt</a>, <a href="Dante%20Gabriel%20Rossetti">Dante Gabriel Rossetti</a> and <a href="John%20Everett%20Millais">John Everett Millais</a>, revived the <a href="Early%20Renaissance">Early Renaissance</a> style with their vivid and detailed style. Prominent amongst 20th-century artists was <a href="Henry%20Moore">Henry Moore</a>, regarded as the voice of British sculpture, and of British modernism in general. More recent painters include <a href="Lucian%20Freud">Lucian Freud</a>, whose work "<a href="Benefits%20Supervisor%20Sleeping">Benefits Supervisor Sleeping</a>" in 2008 set a world record for sale value of a painting by a then-living artist. The <a href="Royal%20Society%20of%20Arts">Royal Society of Arts</a> is an organisation committed to the arts and culture.
Literature, poetry, and philosophy.
Early authors such as <a href="Bede">Bede</a> and <a href="Alcuin">Alcuin</a> wrote in Latin. The period of <a href="Old%20English%20literature">Old English literature</a> provided the epic poem "<a href="Beowulf">Beowulf</a>" and the secular prose of the "<a href="Anglo-Saxon%20Chronicle">Anglo-Saxon Chronicle</a>", along with Christian writings such as "<a href="Judith%20%28poem%29">Judith</a>", <a href="C%C3%A6dmon">Cædmon</a>'s "<a href="C%C3%A6dmon">Hymn</a>" and <a href="hagiography">hagiographies</a>. Following the Norman conquest <a href="Latin%20literature">Latin</a> continued amongst the educated classes, as well as an <a href="Anglo-Norman%20literature">Anglo-Norman literature</a>.
<a href="Middle%20English%20literature">Middle English literature</a> emerged with <a href="Geoffrey%20Chaucer">Geoffrey Chaucer</a>, author of "<a href="The%20Canterbury%20Tales">The Canterbury Tales</a>", along with <a href="John%20Gower">Gower</a>, the <a href="Pearl%20Poet">Pearl Poet</a> and <a href="William%20Langland">Langland</a>. <a href="William%20of%20Ockham">William of Ockham</a> and <a href="Roger%20Bacon">Roger Bacon</a>, who were <a href="Franciscans">Franciscans</a>, were major philosophers of the Middle Ages. <a href="Julian%20of%20Norwich">Julian of Norwich</a>, who wrote "<a href="Revelations%20of%20Divine%20Love">Revelations of Divine Love</a>", was a prominent Christian mystic. With the <a href="English%20Renaissance">English Renaissance</a> literature in the <a href="Early%20Modern%20English">Early Modern English</a> style appeared. <a href="William%20Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a>, whose works include "<a href="Hamlet">Hamlet</a>", "<a href="Romeo%20and%20Juliet">Romeo and Juliet</a>", "<a href="Macbeth">Macbeth</a>", and "<a href="A%20Midsummer%20Night%27s%20Dream">A Midsummer Night's Dream</a>", remains one of the most championed authors in English literature.
<a href="Christopher%20Marlowe">Christopher Marlowe</a>, <a href="Edmund%20Spenser">Edmund Spenser</a>, <a href="Philip%20Sydney">Philip Sydney</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Kyd">Thomas Kyd</a>, <a href="John%20Donne">John Donne</a>, and <a href="Ben%20Jonson">Ben Jonson</a> are other established authors of the <a href="Elizabethan%20literature">Elizabethan age</a>. <a href="Francis%20Bacon">Francis Bacon</a> and <a href="Thomas%20Hobbes">Thomas Hobbes</a> wrote on <a href="empiricism">empiricism</a> and <a href="materialism">materialism</a>, including <a href="scientific%20method">scientific method</a> and <a href="social%20contract">social contract</a>. <a href="Robert%20Filmer">Filmer</a> wrote on the <a href="Divine%20Right%20of%20Kings">Divine Right of Kings</a>. <a href="Andrew%20Marvell">Marvell</a> was the best-known poet of the <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20England">Commonwealth</a>, while <a href="John%20Milton">John Milton</a> authored "<a href="Paradise%20Lost">Paradise Lost</a>" during the <a href="Restoration%20literature">Restoration</a>.
Some of the most prominent philosophers of the <a href="Age%20of%20Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> were <a href="John%20Locke">John Locke</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Paine">Thomas Paine</a>, <a href="Samuel%20Johnson">Samuel Johnson</a> and <a href="Jeremy%20Bentham">Jeremy Bentham</a>. More radical elements were later countered by <a href="Edmund%20Burke">Edmund Burke</a> who is regarded as the founder of conservatism. The poet <a href="Alexander%20Pope">Alexander Pope</a> with his satirical verse became well regarded. The English played a significant role in <a href="romanticism">romanticism</a>: <a href="Samuel%20Taylor%20Coleridge">Samuel Taylor Coleridge</a>, <a href="Lord%20Byron">Lord Byron</a>, <a href="John%20Keats">John Keats</a>, <a href="Mary%20Shelley">Mary Shelley</a>, <a href="Percy%20Bysshe%20Shelley">Percy Bysshe Shelley</a>, <a href="William%20Blake">William Blake</a> and <a href="William%20Wordsworth">William Wordsworth</a> were major figures.
In response to the <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>, agrarian writers sought a way between <a href="liberty">liberty</a> and tradition; <a href="William%20Cobbett">William Cobbett</a>, <a href="G.%20K.%20Chesterton">G. K. Chesterton</a> and <a href="Hilaire%20Belloc">Hilaire Belloc</a> were main exponents, while the founder of <a href="guild%20socialism">guild socialism</a>, <a href="Arthur%20Penty">Arthur Penty</a>, and <a href="cooperative%20movement">cooperative movement</a> advocate <a href="G.%20D.%20H.%20Cole">G. D. H. Cole</a> are somewhat related. Empiricism continued through <a href="John%20Stuart%20Mill">John Stuart Mill</a> and <a href="Bertrand%20Russell">Bertrand Russell</a>, while <a href="Bernard%20Williams">Bernard Williams</a> was involved in <a href="analytics">analytics</a>. Authors from around the <a href="Victorian%20era">Victorian era</a> include <a href="Charles%20Dickens">Charles Dickens</a>, the <a href="Bront%C3%AB%20sisters">Brontë sisters</a>, <a href="Jane%20Austen">Jane Austen</a>, <a href="George%20Eliot">George Eliot</a>, <a href="Rudyard%20Kipling">Rudyard Kipling</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Hardy">Thomas Hardy</a>, <a href="H.%20G.%20Wells">H. G. Wells</a> and <a href="Lewis%20Carroll">Lewis Carroll</a>. Since then England has continued to produce novelists such as <a href="George%20Orwell">George Orwell</a>, <a href="D.%20H.%20Lawrence">D. H. Lawrence</a>, <a href="Virginia%20Woolf">Virginia Woolf</a>, <a href="C.%20S.%20Lewis">C. S. Lewis</a>, <a href="Enid%20Blyton">Enid Blyton</a>, <a href="Aldous%20Huxley">Aldous Huxley</a>, <a href="Agatha%20Christie">Agatha Christie</a>, <a href="Terry%20Pratchett">Terry Pratchett</a>, <a href="J.%20R.%20R.%20Tolkien">J. R. R. Tolkien</a>, and <a href="J.%20K.%20Rowling">J. K. Rowling</a>.
Performing arts.
The traditional <a href="folk%20music%20of%20England">folk music of England</a> is centuries old and has contributed to several genres prominently; mostly <a href="sea%20shanties">sea shanties</a>, <a href="jig">jig</a>s, <a href="hornpipe">hornpipe</a>s and <a href="dance%20music">dance music</a>. It has its own distinct variations and regional peculiarities. Ballads featuring Robin Hood, printed by <a href="Wynkyn%20de%20Worde">Wynkyn de Worde</a> in the 16th century, are an important artefact, as are <a href="John%20Playford">John Playford</a>'s "<a href="The%20Dancing%20Master">The Dancing Master</a>" and <a href="Robert%20Harley%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Oxford%20and%20Earl%20Mortimer">Robert Harley's</a> "<a href="Roxburghe%20Ballads">Roxburghe Ballads</a>" collections. Some of the best-known songs are "<a href="Greensleeves">Greensleeves</a>", "<a href="Pastime%20with%20Good%20Company">Pastime with Good Company</a>", "<a href="Maggie%20May%20%28folk%20song%29">Maggie May</a>" and "<a href="Spanish%20Ladies">Spanish Ladies</a>" amongst others. Many <a href="nursery%20rhymes">nursery rhymes</a> are of English origin such as "<a href="Mary%2C%20Mary%2C%20Quite%20Contrary">Mary, Mary, Quite Contrary</a>", "<a href="Roses%20Are%20Red">Roses Are Red</a>", "<a href="Jack%20and%20Jill%20%28nursery%20rhyme%29">Jack and Jill</a>", "<a href="London%20Bridge%20Is%20Falling%20Down">London Bridge Is Falling Down</a>, <a href="The%20Grand%20Old%20Duke%20of%20York">The Grand Old Duke of York</a>, <a href="Hey%20Diddle%20Diddle">Hey Diddle Diddle</a>" and "<a href="Humpty%20Dumpty">Humpty Dumpty</a>". Traditional English Christmas carols include "<a href="We%20Wish%20You%20a%20Merry%20Christmas">We Wish You a Merry Christmas</a>", "<a href="The%20First%20Noel">The First Noel</a>", “<a href="I%20Saw%20Three%20Ships">I Saw Three Ships</a>” and "<a href="God%20Rest%20You%20Merry%2C%20Gentlemen">God Rest You Merry, Gentlemen</a>".
Early English composers in classical music include Renaissance artists <a href="Thomas%20Tallis">Thomas Tallis</a> and <a href="William%20Byrd">William Byrd</a>, followed up by <a href="Henry%20Purcell">Henry Purcell</a> from the <a href="Baroque%20music">Baroque period</a>. German-born <a href="George%20Frideric%20Handel">George Frideric Handel</a> spent most of his composing life in London and became a national icon in Britain, creating some of the most well-known works of classical music, especially his English oratorios, "<a href="Messiah%20%28Handel%29">The Messiah</a>", "<a href="Solomon%20%28Handel%29">Solomon</a>", "<a href="Water%20Music%20%28Handel%29">Water Music</a>", and "<a href="Music%20for%20the%20Royal%20Fireworks">Music for the Royal Fireworks</a>". One of his four <a href="Coronation%20Anthems%20%28Handel%29">Coronation Anthems</a>, "<a href="Zadok%20the%20Priest">Zadok the Priest</a>", composed for the coronation of <a href="George%20II%20of%20Great%20Britain">George II</a>, has been performed at every subsequent <a href="Coronation%20of%20the%20British%20monarch">British coronation</a>, traditionally during the sovereign's anointing. 
Classical music attracted much attention from 1784 with the formation of the <a href="Birmingham%20Triennial%20Music%20Festival">Birmingham Triennial Music Festival</a>, which was the longest running classical music festival of its kind until the final concerts in 1912. The <a href="English%20Musical%20Renaissance">English Musical Renaissance</a> was a hypothetical development in the late 19th and early 20th century, when English composers, often those lecturing or trained at the <a href="Royal%20College%20of%20Music">Royal College of Music</a>, were said to have freed themselves from foreign musical influences. There was a revival in the profile of composers from England in the 20th century led by <a href="Edward%20Elgar">Edward Elgar</a>, <a href="Benjamin%20Britten">Benjamin Britten</a>, <a href="Frederick%20Delius">Frederick Delius</a>, <a href="Gustav%20Holst">Gustav Holst</a>, <a href="Ralph%20Vaughan%20Williams">Ralph Vaughan Williams</a> and others. Present-day composers from England include <a href="Michael%20Nyman">Michael Nyman</a>, best known for "<a href="The%20Piano">The Piano</a>", and <a href="Andrew%20Lloyd%20Webber">Andrew Lloyd Webber</a>, whose musicals have achieved enormous success in the <a href="West%20End%20theatre">West End</a> and worldwide.
In <a href="popular%20music">popular music</a>, many English bands and solo artists have been cited as the most influential and best-selling musicians of all time. Acts such as <a href="The%20Beatles">The Beatles</a>, <a href="Led%20Zeppelin">Led Zeppelin</a>, <a href="Pink%20Floyd">Pink Floyd</a>, <a href="Elton%20John">Elton John</a>, <a href="Queen%20%28band%29">Queen</a>, <a href="Rod%20Stewart">Rod Stewart</a>, <a href="David%20Bowie">David Bowie</a>, <a href="The%20Rolling%20Stones">The Rolling Stones</a> and <a href="Def%20Leppard">Def Leppard</a> are among the highest-selling recording artists in the world. Many musical genres have origins in (or strong associations with) England, such as <a href="British%20invasion">British invasion</a>, <a href="progressive%20rock">progressive rock</a>, <a href="hard%20rock">hard rock</a>, <a href="mod%20%28subculture%29">Mod</a>, <a href="glam%20rock">glam rock</a>, <a href="heavy%20metal%20music">heavy metal</a>, <a href="Britpop">Britpop</a>, <a href="indie%20rock">indie rock</a>, <a href="gothic%20rock">gothic rock</a>, <a href="shoegazing">shoegazing</a>, <a href="acid%20house">acid house</a>, <a href="UK%20garage">garage</a>, <a href="trip%20hop">trip hop</a>, <a href="drum%20and%20bass">drum and bass</a> and <a href="dubstep">dubstep</a>.
Large outdoor <a href="List%20of%20music%20festivals%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">music festivals</a> in the summer and autumn are popular, such as <a href="Glastonbury%20Festival">Glastonbury</a>, <a href="V%20Festival">V Festival</a>, and the <a href="Reading%20and%20Leeds%20Festivals">Reading and Leeds Festivals</a>. England was at the forefront of the illegal, free <a href="rave">rave</a> movement from the late 1980s, which led to pan-European culture of <a href="Teknival">teknivals</a> mirrored on the UK free festival movement and associated travelling lifestyle. The <a href="Boishakhi%20Mela">Boishakhi Mela</a> is a <a href="Bengali%20New%20Year">Bengali New Year</a> festival celebrated by the <a href="British%20Bangladeshi">British Bangladeshi</a> community. It is the largest open-air Asian festival in Europe. After the <a href="Notting%20Hill%20Carnival">Notting Hill Carnival</a>, it is the second-largest street festival in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a> attracting over 80,000 visitors from across the country. 
The most prominent <a href="opera%20house">opera house</a> in England is the <a href="Royal%20Opera%20House">Royal Opera House</a> at <a href="Covent%20Garden">Covent Garden</a>. <a href="The%20Proms">The Proms</a> – a season of <a href="orchestral">orchestral</a> classical concerts held primarily at the <a href="Royal%20Albert%20Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a> in London – is a major cultural event in the English calendar, and takes place yearly. <a href="The%20Royal%20Ballet">The Royal Ballet</a> is one of the world's foremost classical ballet companies, its reputation built on two prominent figures of 20th-century dance, "<a href="prima%20ballerina">prima ballerina</a>" <a href="Margot%20Fonteyn">Margot Fonteyn</a> and choreographer <a href="Frederick%20Ashton">Frederick Ashton</a>. The <a href="Royal%20Academy%20of%20Music">Royal Academy of Music</a> is the oldest <a href="Music%20school">conservatoire</a> in England, founded in 1822. It received its <a href="royal%20charter">royal charter</a> in 1830 from <a href="George%20IV%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">King George IV</a>. England is home to numerous major orchestras such as the <a href="BBC%20Symphony%20Orchestra">BBC Symphony Orchestra</a>, the <a href="Royal%20Philharmonic%20Orchestra">Royal Philharmonic Orchestra</a>, the <a href="Philharmonia%20Orchestra">Philharmonia Orchestra</a>, and the <a href="London%20Symphony%20Orchestra">London Symphony Orchestra</a>.
The <a href="circus">circus</a> is a traditional form of entertainment in England. <a href="Chipperfield%27s%20Circus">Chipperfield's Circus</a> dates back more than 300 years, making it one of the oldest family circus dynasties. <a href="Philip%20Astley">Philip Astley</a> is regarded as the father of the <a href="Circus%23Development">modern circus</a>. Following his invention of the circus ring in 1768, <a href="Astley%27s%20Amphitheatre">Astley's Amphitheatre</a> opened in London in 1773. As an equestrian master Astley had a skill for trick horse-riding, and when he added tumblers, <a href="tightrope">tightrope</a>-walkers, <a href="jugglers">jugglers</a>, performing dogs, and a <a href="clown">clown</a> to fill time between his own demonstrations – the modern circus was born.
<a href="Pantomime">Pantomime</a> is a British <a href="Musical%20theatre">musical comedy</a> stage production, designed for family entertainment. It is performed in theatres throughout the England during the Christmas and New Year season. The art originated in the 18th century with <a href="John%20Weaver%20%28dancer%29">John Weaver</a>, a dance master and choreographer. In 19th century England it acquired its present form, which includes songs, slapstick comedy and dancing, employing gender-crossing actors, combining topical humour with a story loosely based on a well-known fairy tale.
Cinema.
England (and the UK as a whole) has had a considerable influence on the history of the cinema, producing some of the greatest actors, directors and motion pictures of all time, including <a href="Alfred%20Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a>, <a href="Charlie%20Chaplin">Charlie Chaplin</a>, <a href="David%20Lean">David Lean</a>, <a href="Laurence%20Olivier">Laurence Olivier</a>, <a href="Vivien%20Leigh">Vivien Leigh</a>, <a href="John%20Gielgud">John Gielgud</a>, <a href="Peter%20Sellers">Peter Sellers</a>, <a href="Julie%20Andrews">Julie Andrews</a>, <a href="Michael%20Caine">Michael Caine</a>, <a href="Gary%20Oldman">Gary Oldman</a>, <a href="Helen%20Mirren">Helen Mirren</a>, <a href="Kate%20Winslet">Kate Winslet</a> and <a href="Daniel%20Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a>. Hitchcock and Lean are among the most critically acclaimed filmmakers. Hitchcock's first thriller, "" (1926), helped shape the <a href="Thriller%20film">thriller</a> genre in film, while his 1929 film, "<a href="Blackmail%20%281929%20film%29">Blackmail</a>", is often regarded as the first British feature film.
Major film studios in England include <a href="Pinewood%20Studios">Pinewood</a>, <a href="Elstree%20Studios">Elstree</a> and <a href="Shepperton%20Studios">Shepperton</a>. Some of the most commercially successful films of all time have been produced in England, including two of the <a href="List%20of%20highest-grossing%20film%20series">highest-grossing film franchises</a> ("<a href="Harry%20Potter%20%28film%20series%29">Harry Potter</a>" and "<a href="James%20Bond%20%28film%20series%29">James Bond</a>"). <a href="Ealing%20Studios">Ealing Studios</a> in London has a claim to being the oldest continuously working film studio in the world. Famous for recording many motion picture <a href="film%20scores">film scores</a>, the <a href="London%20Symphony%20Orchestra">London Symphony Orchestra</a> first performed film music in 1935. The <a href="Hammer%20Film%20Productions">Hammer Horror</a> films starring <a href="Christopher%20Lee">Christopher Lee</a> saw the production of the first gory horror films showing blood and guts in colour.
The <a href="BFI%20Top%20100%20British%20films">BFI Top 100 British films</a> includes "<a href="Monty%20Python%27s%20Life%20of%20Brian">Monty Python's Life of Brian</a>" (1979), a film regularly voted the funniest of all time by the UK public. English producers are also active in <a href="international%20co-productions">international co-productions</a> and English actors, directors and crew feature regularly in American films. The UK film council ranked <a href="David%20Yates">David Yates</a>, <a href="Christopher%20Nolan">Christopher Nolan</a>, <a href="Mike%20Newell%20%28director%29">Mike Newell</a>, <a href="Ridley%20Scott">Ridley Scott</a> and <a href="Paul%20Greengrass">Paul Greengrass</a> the five most commercially successful English directors since 2001. Other contemporary English directors include <a href="Sam%20Mendes">Sam Mendes</a>, <a href="Guy%20Ritchie">Guy Ritchie</a> and <a href="Richard%20Curtis">Richard Curtis</a>. Current actors include <a href="Tom%20Hardy">Tom Hardy</a>, <a href="Daniel%20Craig">Daniel Craig</a>, <a href="Benedict%20Cumberbatch">Benedict Cumberbatch</a>, <a href="Lena%20Headey">Lena Headey</a>, <a href="Felicity%20Jones">Felicity Jones</a>, <a href="Emilia%20Clarke">Emilia Clarke</a>, <a href="Lashana%20Lynch">Lashana Lynch</a>, and <a href="Emma%20Watson">Emma Watson</a>. Acclaimed for his motion capture work, <a href="Andy%20Serkis">Andy Serkis</a> opened <a href="The%20Imaginarium%20Studios">The Imaginarium Studios</a> in London in 2011. The visual effects company <a href="Framestore">Framestore</a> in London has produced some of the most critically acclaimed special effects in modern film. Many successful Hollywood films have been based on English people, <a href="British%20literature">stories</a> or events. The <a href="List%20of%20Walt%20Disney%20Animation%20Studios%20films">'English Cycle'</a> of Disney animated films include "<a href="Alice%20in%20Wonderland">Alice in Wonderland</a>", "<a href="The%20Jungle%20Book">The Jungle Book</a>" and "<a href="Winnie%20the%20Pooh">Winnie the Pooh</a>".
Museums, libraries, and galleries.
<a href="English%20Heritage">English Heritage</a> is a governmental body with a broad remit of managing the historic sites, artefacts and environments of England. It is currently sponsored by the <a href="Department%20for%20Digital%2C%20Culture%2C%20Media%20and%20Sport">Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport</a>. The charity <a href="National%20Trust%20for%20Places%20of%20Historic%20Interest%20or%20Natural%20Beauty">National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty</a> holds a contrasting role. 17 of the 25 United Kingdom UNESCO <a href="World%20Heritage%20Site">World Heritage Site</a>s fall within England. Some of the best-known of these are: <a href="Hadrian%27s%20Wall">Hadrian's Wall</a>, <a href="Stonehenge%2C%20Avebury%20and%20Associated%20Sites">Stonehenge, Avebury and Associated Sites</a>, <a href="Tower%20of%20London">Tower of London</a>, <a href="Jurassic%20Coast">Jurassic Coast</a>, <a href="Saltaire">Saltaire</a>, <a href="Ironbridge%20Gorge">Ironbridge Gorge</a>, <a href="Studley%20Royal%20Park">Studley Royal Park</a> and various others.
There are many museums in England, but perhaps the most notable is London's <a href="British%20Museum">British Museum</a>. Its collection of more than seven million objects is one of the largest and most comprehensive in the world, sourced from every continent, illustrating and documenting the story of human culture from its beginning to the present. The <a href="British%20Library">British Library</a> in London is the <a href="national%20library">national library</a> and is one of the world's largest <a href="research%20libraries">research libraries</a>, holding over 150 million items in almost all known languages and formats; including around 25 million books. The most senior art gallery is the <a href="National%20Gallery">National Gallery</a> in <a href="Trafalgar%20Square">Trafalgar Square</a>, which houses a collection of over 2,300 paintings dating from the mid-13th century to 1900. The <a href="Tate">Tate</a> galleries house the national collections of British and international modern art; they also host the famously controversial <a href="Turner%20Prize">Turner Prize</a>.
Media.
The <a href="BBC">BBC</a>, founded in 1922, is the UK's publicly funded radio, television and Internet broadcasting corporation, and is the oldest and largest broadcaster in the world. It operates numerous television and radio stations in the UK and abroad and its domestic services are funded by the <a href="Television%20licensing%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">television licence</a>. The <a href="BBC%20World%20Service">BBC World Service</a> is an <a href="International%20broadcasting">international broadcaster</a> owned and operated by the <a href="BBC">BBC</a>. It is the world's largest of any kind. It broadcasts radio <a href="news">news</a>, <a href="speech">speech</a> and <a href="discussions">discussions</a> in more than 40 languages. 
London dominates the media sector in England: national newspapers and television and radio are largely based there, although Manchester is also a significant national media centre. The UK publishing sector, including books, directories and databases, journals, magazines and business media, newspapers and news agencies, has a combined turnover of around £20 billion and employs around 167,000 people. National newspapers produced in England include "<a href="The%20Times">The Times</a>", "<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>" and the "<a href="Financial%20Times">Financial Times</a>". 
Magazines and journals published in England that have achieved worldwide circulation include "<a href="Nature%20%28journal%29">Nature</a>", "<a href="New%20Scientist">New Scientist</a>", "<a href="The%20Spectator">The Spectator</a>", "<a href="Prospect%20%28magazine%29">Prospect</a>", "<a href="NME">NME</a>" and "<a href="The%20Economist">The Economist</a>". The <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20Digital%2C%20Culture%2C%20Media%20and%20Sport">Secretary of State for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport</a> has overall responsibility over media and broadcasting in England. 
Sport.
England has a strong sporting heritage, and during the 19th century codified many sports that are now played around the world. Sports originating in England include <a href="association%20football">association football</a>, <a href="cricket">cricket</a>, <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a>, <a href="tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="boxing">boxing</a>, badminton, <a href="squash%20%28sport%29">squash</a>, <a href="rounders">rounders</a>, <a href="field%20hockey">hockey</a>, <a href="snooker">snooker</a>, <a href="billiards">billiards</a>, <a href="darts">darts</a>, table tennis, <a href="bowls">bowls</a>, <a href="netball">netball</a>, <a href="thoroughbred">thoroughbred</a> horseracing, <a href="greyhound%20racing">greyhound racing</a> and <a href="fox%20hunting">fox hunting</a>. It has helped the development of <a href="golf">golf</a>, sailing and <a href="Formula%20One">Formula One</a>.
Football is the <a href="Sport%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom%23Popularity">most popular</a> of these sports. The <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England national football team</a>, whose home venue is <a href="Wembley%20Stadium">Wembley Stadium</a>, played <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> in the first ever international football match in 1872. Referred to as the "home of football" by <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a>, England hosted the <a href="1966%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1966 FIFA World Cup</a>, and won the tournament by defeating <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">West Germany</a> 4–2 in the <a href="1966%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20Final">final</a>, with <a href="Geoff%20Hurst">Geoff Hurst</a> scoring a <a href="hat-trick">hat-trick</a>. With a British television audience peak of 32.30 million viewers, the final is the <a href="List%20of%20most-watched%20television%20broadcasts%23United%20Kingdom">most watched television event ever</a> in the UK.
At club level, England is recognised by FIFA as the birthplace of club football, due to <a href="Sheffield%20F.C.">Sheffield F.C.</a> founded in 1857 being the world's oldest club. <a href="The%20Football%20Association">The Football Association</a> is the oldest governing body in the sport, with the <a href="Laws%20of%20the%20Game%20%28association%20football%29">rules</a> of football first drafted in 1863 by <a href="Ebenezer%20Cobb%20Morley">Ebenezer Cobb Morley</a>. The <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> and <a href="The%20Football%20League">The Football League</a> were the first cup and league competitions respectively. In the modern day, the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> is the world's most-watched football league, most lucrative, and amongst the elite.
As is the case throughout the UK, football in England is notable for the rivalries between clubs and the passion of the supporters, which includes a tradition of football chants. The most successful English football team in the European Cup/UEFA Champions League is <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool F.C.</a> who have won the competition on six occasions. Other English success has come from <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United F.C.</a>, winning the competition on 3 occasions; <a href="Nottingham%20Forest%20F.C.">Nottingham Forest F.C.</a> and <a href="Chelsea%20F.C.">Chelsea F.C.</a> on 2 occasions, <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa F.C.</a> have only won the trophy once.
<a href="Cricket">Cricket</a> is generally thought to have been developed in the early medieval period among the farming and metalworking communities of the <a href="Weald">Weald</a>. The <a href="England%20cricket%20team">England cricket team</a> is a composite England and Wales, team. One of the game's top rivalries is <a href="The%20Ashes">The Ashes</a> series between England and <a href="Australia%20cricket%20team">Australia</a>, contested since 1882. The climax of the <a href="2005%20Ashes%20series">2005 Ashes</a> was viewed by 7.4 million as it was available on terrestrial television. England has hosted five <a href="Cricket%20World%20Cup">Cricket World Cup</a>s (1975, 1979, 1983, 1999 and <a href="2019%20Cricket%20World%20Cup">2019</a>), winning the 2019 edition in a final regarded as one of the greatest one day internationals ever played. They hosted the <a href="ICC%20World%20Twenty20">ICC World Twenty20</a> in <a href="2009%20ICC%20World%20Twenty20">2009</a>, winning this format in 2010 beating rivals Australia in the final. In the domestic competition, the <a href="County%20Championship">County Championship</a>, <a href="Yorkshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Yorkshire</a> are by far the most successful club having won the competition 32 times outright and sharing it on 1 other occasion. <a href="Lord%27s%20Cricket%20Ground">Lord's Cricket Ground</a> situated in London is sometimes referred to as the "Mecca of Cricket".
<a href="William%20Penny%20Brookes">William Penny Brookes</a> was prominent in organising the format for the modern <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a>. In 1994, then President of the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">IOC</a>, <a href="Juan%20Antonio%20Samaranch">Juan Antonio Samaranch</a>, laid a wreath on Brooke's grave, and said, "I came to pay homage and tribute to Dr Brookes, who really was the founder of the modern Olympic Games". London has hosted the <a href="Summer%20Olympic%20Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> three times, in <a href="1908%20Summer%20Olympics">1908</a>, <a href="1948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948</a>, and <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012</a>. England competes in the <a href="Commonwealth%20Games">Commonwealth Games</a>, held every four years. <a href="Sport%20England">Sport England</a> is the governing body responsible for distributing funds and providing strategic guidance for sporting activity in England. The <a href="Minister%20for%20Sport%20and%20Civil%20Society">Minister for Sport and Civil Society</a> has responsibility for sport in England.
<a href="Rugby%20union">Rugby union</a> originated in <a href="Rugby%20School">Rugby School</a>, Warwickshire in the early 19th century. The <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England rugby union team</a> won the <a href="2003%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2003 Rugby World Cup</a>, with <a href="Jonny%20Wilkinson">Jonny Wilkinson</a> scoring the winning <a href="drop%20kick">drop goal</a> in the last minute of extra time against Australia. England was one of the host nations of the competition in the <a href="1991%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">1991 Rugby World Cup</a> and also hosted the <a href="2015%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2015 Rugby World Cup</a>. The top level of club participation is the <a href="Guinness%20Premiership">English Premiership</a>. <a href="Leicester%20Tigers">Leicester Tigers</a>, <a href="Wasps%20RFC">London Wasps</a>, <a href="Bath%20Rugby">Bath Rugby</a> and <a href="Northampton%20Saints">Northampton Saints</a> have had success in the Europe-wide <a href="Heineken%20Cup">Heineken Cup</a>.
<a href="Rugby%20league">Rugby league</a> was born in <a href="Huddersfield">Huddersfield</a> in 1895. Since 2008, the <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England national rugby league team</a> has been a full test nation in lieu of the <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain national rugby league team</a>, which won three <a href="Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">World Cups</a> but is now retired. Club sides play in <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a>, the present-day embodiment of the <a href="Rugby%20Football%20League%20Championship">Rugby Football League Championship</a>. Rugby League is most popular among towns in the northern English counties of <a href="Lancashire">Lancashire</a>, Yorkshire and <a href="Cumbria">Cumbria</a>. The vast majority of English clubs in Super League are based in the north of England. Some of the most successful clubs include <a href="Wigan%20Warriors">Wigan Warriors</a>, <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a>, <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds Rhinos</a> and <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield Giants</a>; the former three have all won the <a href="World%20Club%20Challenge">World Club Challenge</a> previously.
<a href="Golf">Golf</a> has been prominent in England; due in part to its cultural and geographical ties to Scotland, the <a href="Golf%20in%20Scotland">home of Golf</a>. There are both professional tours for men and women, in two main tours: the <a href="Professional%20Golfers%20Association">PGA</a> and the <a href="European%20Tour">European Tour</a>. England has produced grand slam winners: <a href="Cyril%20Walker%20%28golfer%29">Cyril Walker</a>, <a href="Tony%20Jacklin">Tony Jacklin</a>, <a href="Nick%20Faldo">Nick Faldo</a>, and <a href="Justin%20Rose">Justin Rose</a> in the men's and <a href="Laura%20Davies">Laura Davies</a>, <a href="Alison%20Nicholas">Alison Nicholas</a>, and <a href="Karen%20Stupples">Karen Stupples</a> in the women's. The world's oldest golf tournament, and golf's first major is <a href="The%20Open%20Championship">The Open Championship</a>, played both in England and Scotland. The biennial golf competition, the <a href="Ryder%20Cup">Ryder Cup</a>, is named after English businessman <a href="Samuel%20Ryder">Samuel Ryder</a> who sponsored the event and donated the trophy. Nick Faldo is the most successful Ryder Cup player ever, having won the most points (25) of any player on either the European or US teams.
<a href="Tennis">Tennis</a> was created in Birmingham in the late 19th century, and <a href="The%20Championships%2C%20Wimbledon">the Wimbledon Championships</a> is the oldest tennis tournament in the world, and widely considered the most prestigious. Wimbledon is a tournament that has a major place in the British cultural calendar. <a href="Fred%20Perry">Fred Perry</a> was the last Englishman to win Wimbledon in 1936. He was the first player to win all four <a href="Grand%20Slam%20in%20tennis">Grand Slam</a> singles titles and helped lead the <a href="Great%20Britain%20Davis%20Cup%20team">Great Britain</a> team to four <a href="Davis%20Cup">Davis Cup</a> wins. English women who have won Wimbledon include: <a href="Ann%20Haydon%20Jones">Ann Haydon Jones</a> in 1969 and <a href="Virginia%20Wade">Virginia Wade</a> in 1977.
In <a href="boxing">boxing</a>, under the <a href="Marquess%20of%20Queensberry%20Rules">Marquess of Queensberry Rules</a>, England has produced many world champions across the weight divisions internationally recognised by the governing bodies. World champions include <a href="Bob%20Fitzsimmons">Bob Fitzsimmons</a>, <a href="Ted%20%26quot%3BKid%26quot%3B%20Lewis">Ted "Kid" Lewis</a>, <a href="Randolph%20Turpin">Randolph Turpin</a>, <a href="Nigel%20Benn">Nigel Benn</a>, <a href="Chris%20Eubank">Chris Eubank</a>, <a href="Frank%20Bruno">Frank Bruno</a>, <a href="Lennox%20Lewis">Lennox Lewis</a>, <a href="Ricky%20Hatton">Ricky Hatton</a>, <a href="Naseem%20Hamed">Naseem Hamed</a>, <a href="Amir%20Khan%20%28British%20boxer%29">Amir Khan</a>, <a href="Carl%20Froch">Carl Froch</a>, and <a href="David%20Haye">David Haye</a>.
