In women's boxing, <a href="Nicola%20Adams">Nicola Adams</a> became the world's first woman to win an Olympic boxing gold medal at the <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>.
Originating in 17th and 18th-century England, the <a href="thoroughbred">thoroughbred</a> is a horse breed best known for its use in <a href="horse%20racing">horse racing</a>. The <a href="National%20Hunt">National Hunt</a> horse race the <a href="Grand%20National">Grand National</a>, is held annually at <a href="Aintree%20Racecourse">Aintree Racecourse</a> in early April. It is the most watched horse race in the UK, attracting casual observers, and three-time winner <a href="Red%20Rum">Red Rum</a> is the most successful racehorse in the event's history. Red Rum is also the best-known racehorse in the country.
The <a href="1950%20British%20Grand%20Prix">1950 British Grand Prix</a> at <a href="Silverstone%20Circuit">Silverstone</a> was the first race in the newly created <a href="Formula%20One%20World%20Championship">Formula One World Championship</a>. Since then, England has produced some of the greatest drivers in the sport, including; <a href="John%20Surtees">John Surtees</a>, <a href="Stirling%20Moss">Stirling Moss</a>, <a href="Graham%20Hill">Graham Hill</a> (only driver to have won the <a href="Triple%20Crown%20of%20Motorsport">Triple Crown</a>), <a href="Nigel%20Mansell">Nigel Mansell</a> (only man to hold F1 and IndyCar titles at the same time), <a href="Damon%20Hill">Damon Hill</a>, <a href="Lewis%20Hamilton">Lewis Hamilton</a> and <a href="Jenson%20Button">Jenson Button</a>. It has manufactured some of the most technically advanced racing cars, and many of today's racing companies choose England as their base of operations for its engineering knowledge and organisation. <a href="McLaren%20Automotive">McLaren Automotive</a>, <a href="Williams%20F1">Williams F1</a>, <a href="Team%20Lotus">Team Lotus</a>, <a href="Honda">Honda</a>, <a href="Brawn%20GP">Brawn GP</a>, <a href="Benetton%20Formula">Benetton</a>, <a href="Renault">Renault</a>, and <a href="Red%20Bull%20Racing">Red Bull Racing</a> are all, or have been, located in the south of England. England also has a rich heritage in <a href="Grand%20Prix%20motorcycle%20racing">Grand Prix motorcycle racing</a>, the premier championship of motorcycle <a href="road%20racing">road racing</a>, and produced several World Champions across all the various class of motorcycle: <a href="Mike%20Hailwood">Mike Hailwood</a>, <a href="John%20Surtees">John Surtees</a>, <a href="Phil%20Read">Phil Read</a>, <a href="Geoff%20Duke">Geoff Duke</a>, and <a href="Barry%20Sheene">Barry Sheene</a>.
<a href="Darts">Darts</a> is a widely popular sport in England; a professional competitive sport, darts is a traditional <a href="pub%20game">pub game</a>. The sport is governed by the <a href="World%20Darts%20Federation">World Darts Federation</a>, one of its member organisations is the <a href="British%20Darts%20Organisation">British Darts Organisation</a> (BDO), which annually stages the <a href="BDO%20World%20Darts%20Championship">BDO World Darts Championship</a>, the other being the <a href="Professional%20Darts%20Corporation">Professional Darts Corporation</a> (PDC), which runs its own world championship at <a href="Alexandra%20Palace">Alexandra Palace</a> in London. <a href="Phil%20Taylor%20%28darts%20player%29">Phil Taylor</a> is widely regarded as the best darts player of all time, having won 187 professional tournaments, and a record 16 <a href="World%20Professional%20Darts%20Championship">World Championships</a>. <a href="Trina%20Gulliver">Trina Gulliver</a> is the ten-time Women's World Professional Darts Champion of the British Darts Organisation. Another popular sport commonly associated with pub games is <a href="Snooker">Snooker</a>, and England has produced several world champions, including <a href="Steve%20Davis">Steve Davis</a> and <a href="Ronnie%20O%27Sullivan">Ronnie O'Sullivan</a>.
The English are keen sailors and enjoy competitive <a href="sailing">sailing</a>; founding and winning some of the world's most famous and respected international competitive tournaments across the various race formats, including the <a href="match%20race">match race</a>, a regatta, and the <a href="America%27s%20Cup">America's Cup</a>. England has produced some of the world's greatest sailors, including <a href="Francis%20Chichester">Francis Chichester</a>, <a href="Herbert%20Hasler">Herbert Hasler</a>, <a href="John%20Ridgway%20%28sailor%29">John Ridgway</a>, <a href="Robin%20Knox-Johnston">Robin Knox-Johnston</a>, <a href="Ellen%20MacArthur">Ellen MacArthur</a>, <a href="Mike%20Golding">Mike Golding</a>, <a href="Paul%20Goodison">Paul Goodison</a>, and the most successful Olympic sailor ever <a href="Ben%20Ainslie">Ben Ainslie</a>.
National symbols.
The St George's Cross has been the national <a href="flag%20of%20England">flag of England</a> since the 13th century. Originally the flag was used by the maritime <a href="Republic%20of%20Genoa">Republic of Genoa</a>. The English monarch paid a tribute to the <a href="Doge%20of%20Genoa">Doge of Genoa</a> from 1190 onwards so that English ships could fly the flag as a means of protection when entering the Mediterranean.
A red cross was a symbol for many <a href="Crusaders">Crusaders</a> in the 12th and 13th centuries. It became associated with <a href="Saint%20George">Saint George</a>, along with countries and cities, which claimed him as their <a href="patron%20saint">patron saint</a> and used his cross as a banner. Since 1606 the St George's Cross has formed part of the design of the <a href="Union%20Flag">Union Flag</a>, a Pan-British flag designed by King <a href="James%20I%20of%20England">James I</a>. During the <a href="English%20Civil%20War">English Civil War</a> and <a href="Interregnum%20%28England%29">Interregnum</a>, the <a href="New%20Model%20Army">New Model Army's</a> standards and the <a href="English%20Commonwealth">Commonwealth's</a> <a href="Great%20Seal%20of%20the%20Realm%23Commonwealth">Great Seal</a> both incorporated the flag of Saint George.
There are numerous other symbols and symbolic artefacts, both official and unofficial, including the <a href="Tudor%20rose">Tudor rose</a>, the nation's <a href="national%20emblem">floral emblem</a>, and the Three Lions featured on the <a href="Royal%20Arms%20of%20England">Royal Arms of England</a>. The Tudor rose was adopted as a national emblem of England around the time of the <a href="Wars%20of%20the%20Roses">Wars of the Roses</a> as a symbol of peace. It is a <a href="syncreticism">syncretic</a> symbol in that it merged the white rose of the <a href="House%20of%20York">Yorkists</a> and the red rose of the <a href="House%20of%20Lancaster">Lancastrians</a>—cadet branches of the <a href="House%20of%20Plantagenet">Plantagenets</a> who went to war over control of the nation. It is also known as the "Rose of England". The <a href="oak">oak</a> tree is a symbol of England, representing strength and endurance. The <a href="Royal%20Oak">Royal Oak</a> symbol and <a href="Oak%20Apple%20Day">Oak Apple Day</a> commemorate the escape of King <a href="Charles%20II%20of%20England">Charles II</a> from the grasp of the parliamentarians after his father's execution: he hid in an oak tree to avoid detection before safely reaching exile.
The Royal Arms of England, a national <a href="coat%20of%20arms">coat of arms</a> featuring three lions, originated with its adoption by <a href="Richard%20the%20Lionheart">Richard the Lionheart</a> in 1198. It is <a href="blazon">blazon</a>ed as "gules, three lions passant guardant or" and it provides one of the most prominent symbols of England; it is similar to the traditional arms of <a href="Normandy">Normandy</a>. England does not have an official designated national anthem, as the United Kingdom as a whole has "<a href="God%20Save%20the%20Queen">God Save the Queen</a>". However, the following are often considered unofficial <a href="National%20anthem%20of%20England">English national anthems</a>:
"<a href="Jerusalem%20%28hymn%29">Jerusalem</a>", "<a href="Land%20of%20Hope%20and%20Glory">Land of Hope and Glory</a>" (used for England during the <a href="2002%20Commonwealth%20Games">2002 Commonwealth Games</a>), and "<a href="I%20Vow%20to%20Thee%2C%20My%20Country">I Vow to Thee, My Country</a>". England's <a href="National%20Day">National Day</a> is 23 April which is <a href="St%20George%27s%20Day%20in%20England">Saint George's Day</a>: Saint George is the patron saint of England.
